However, many people without COVID also have similarly persistent symptoms, meaning distinguishing Long COVID from background symptomatology in the general population is challenging. The study identifies altered smell/taste as the most specific symptom associated with COVID-19, consistently more common among COVID patients than matched negative controls. The risk of persistent symptoms is higher after reinfection than after first infection, and the overall burden of post-acute symptoms declined over time during the study period.

Early, proactive nasal and oral interventions during acute COVID-19 can prevent new-onset smell and taste loss. In this double-blind RCT (n=379), both a saline-only regimen and a regimen with budesonide nasal spray + chlorhexidine mouthwash cut the prevalence of olfactory/gustatory dysfunction by ~3‚Äì5√ó compared with no intervention and also reduced symptom severity.

Klein et al. conducted a cross-sectional immune phenotyping study of ~275 individuals divided into three groups: those with Long COVID (LC) (persistent symptoms), convalescent COVID (recoveries without persistent symptoms, CC), and healthy controls without known infection. Individuals with Long COVID had higher antibody responses against SARS-CoV-2 antigens (especially Spike, S1, RBD) compared with convalescent people without persistent symptoms, even after accounting for vaccination status. They also showed elevated antibody reactivity against other viral pathogens, particularly Epstein-Barr virus antigens. Immune cell subset differences: LC group had higher levels of non-conventional monocytes (CD14^lowCD16^hi), lower levels of certain dendritic cell subsets (cDC1), elevated activated and double-negative B cell subsets. T-cell cytokine production upon stimulation (e.g., IL-2, IL-4, IL-6 from CD4+; some increase also in CD8+) was higher in LC vs controls. Lower cortisol levels also characterize the LC cohort. Autoantibody profiling found many private autoantigen (and GPCR) reactivities but no large difference in number of autoantibody types vs controls; no strong correlation with severity/symptom clusters.

A new monovalent mRNA booster targeting the XBB.1.5 spike protein induces strong neutralizing antibody responses in previously vaccinated individuals, including against a spectrum of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron subvariants. The booster increases both the potency and breadth of neutralization compared to pre-booster levels, demonstrating that updating vaccine antigen to match emerging variants can meaningfully improve cross-variant protection.

Severe COVID-19 patients often show immune dysregulation not explained solely by ACE2-mediated infection. This study demonstrates that receptor for advanced glycation end products (RAGE) acts as an alternative receptor for SARS-CoV-2, enabling viral entry into monocytes, which normally lack ACE2. Single-cell analyses revealed that RAGE pathway activation is a robust marker of disease severity at admission, declining as patients recover. Direct binding of SARS-CoV-2 Spike RBD to RAGE was confirmed experimentally, and inhibition with small-molecule antagonists blocked monocyte infection. The authors also identify candidate therapeutics, including baricitinib and simvastatin, that may dampen RAGE-mediated immune responses.

Comparing sRAGE levels in healthy controls, asymptomatic COVID-19 patients, and those with lung involvement, the study finds that asymptomatic individuals have elevated sRAGE relative to controls, while those with lung involvement have significantly reduced sRAGE, especially in older age. Inflammatory markers like CRP, ferritin, and fibrinogen are higher in lung-involved cases, reinforcing the link between inflammation, lung pathology, and disease severity. These results suggest that the soluble RAGE receptor may act in part as a protective ‚Äúdecoy‚Äù against maladaptive RAGE pathway activation in COVID-19, and that reductions in its level associate with worse lung disease.

This study assessed whether people with Post-COVID Condition (PCC, aka Long COVID) exhibit generalized cognitive slowing, compared to people who had COVID but do not have long COVID symptoms (No-PCC), and people who never had COVID (No-COVID). The authors recruited ~270 PCC patients from two clinics in the UK and Germany, and used two web-based cognitive tasks: a Simple Reaction Time (SRT) task, and a more sustained attention task Number Vigilance Test (NVT). They also collected self-report measures of fatigue, depression, sleep quality. They found that PCC patients had substantially slowed reaction times even on the simple task: large delays vs both control groups, consistent across both clinic sites. In SRT, many PCC patients fell multiple standard deviations behind controls. On NVT (more demanding), PCC patients showed slower responses (~150‚Äì200 ms slower than both No-COVID and No-PCC controls) and less vigilance. The cognitive slowing was not strongly associated with depression or sleep disturbance (though those were elevated), suggesting that slowing is not entirely explained by mood or sleep problems.

In men infected with the Omicron variant, early post-infection brain imaging reveals detectable structural changes: decreased gray matter thickness in the precuneus and lateral occipital cortex, along with reduced hippocampal volume ratio, relative to pre-infection baselines. A group of 98 male participants had brain MRIs and neuropsychiatric assessments before Omicron wave (‚Äúpre-Omicron baseline‚Äù), and 61 of them were re-evaluated in the acute/post-Omicron period (mean ~ a few weeks after infection). Some (~17) also had 3-month follow-ups. These neuroanatomical changes occur even though most participants had mild infection and were relatively young (mean age ~43), and follow-up at ~3 months indicates many systemic symptoms improve, but the brain structural differences persist. Clinically, these imaging changes are associated with detectable neuropsychiatric effects: heightened anxiety correlates with cortical thinning in the precuneus; cognitive tests like word fluency link with hippocampal volume. Left precuneus thickness: decreased by about 0.14 mm post-infection compared with pre-Omicron baseline. Right lateral occipital thickness: decreased by ~0.12 mm. Right hippocampus volume ratio (to total intracranial volume): decreased by ~0.02%. Correlations: thinner left precuneus correlated with higher anxiety scores (r ‚âà ‚Äì0.29); smaller right hippocampal ratio correlated with lower word fluency (r ‚âà 0.25).

HIV-1 and SARS-CoV-2 differ in how they damage stem-progenitor cells but may share common downstream effects. HIV-1 infects CD4‚Å∫ T cells and indirectly suppresses differentiation of CD34‚Å∫ hematopoietic stem-progenitor cells (HSPCs), in part via altered secretion of miRNAs from infected T cells; this leads to impaired hematopoiesis. By contrast, SARS-CoV-2 directly infects CD133‚Å∫ endothelial stem-progenitor cells (ESPCs) via ACE2, which then likely release miRNAs that dysregulate immune cells (e.g. CD4‚Å∫ T lymphocytes) that themselves do not express ACE2, contributing to cytokine storms and immune dysfunction.

From 1,547 records screened, 25 studies (total 29,213 participants) were included (search to 12 Feb 2023). The pooled incidence of any Long-COVID symptom was 48.6% (95% CI 37.4‚Äì59.8). Psychiatric conditions were most frequent, with PTSD ‚âà 25% (95% CI 21.1‚Äì30.4). Older age (p = 0.027) and hospitalization during acute infection (p = 0.05) were associated with higher Long-COVID frequency.

In a cross-sectional OCT study of 56 people recovered from COVID-19 vs 40 controls, Po√ßas et al. found thinning of ganglion-cell/retinal nerve fiber layers and thickening of the subfoveal choroid, indicating a non-glaucomatous neuropathy-like pattern plus vascular changes in the eye after infection.

Vaccination added on top of previous COVID-19 infection meaningfully improves both the number and quality of spike-specific CD4‚Å∫ and CD8‚Å∫ T cells. The enhanced functionality includes increased cytokine production, polyfunctionality, and effector gene expression. Although markers commonly associated with inhibition or exhaustion (PD-1, TIM-3) are upregulated following vaccination, these do not appear to impair functionality, suggesting that hybrid immunity maintains robust effector potential rather than pushing T cells into dysfunction. In contrast, T cells targeting non-spike viral proteins do not receive a comparable boost from vaccination and instead tend to wane or stay the same over time.

This study investigated skeletal muscle pathology in long COVID patients suffering from persistent fatigue, muscle weakness, and exercise intolerance. Biopsies revealed structural vascular changes, including fewer capillaries and thickened basement membranes, alongside immune alterations such as increased CD169‚Å∫ macrophages and complement system activation. Viral RNA was absent, suggesting that symptoms are driven by immune-mediated and vascular sequelae rather than viral persistence. Transcriptomic profiling confirmed upregulation of immune and angiogenesis genes and downregulation of metabolic and mitochondrial pathways, while serum proteomics showed increased complement proteins.

üß´Healthy human neutrophils exposed to SARS-CoV-2 or to supernatant from infected epithelial cells show dysfunctional degranulation: the release of the primary granule enzyme myeloperoxidase is reduced, while elastase release is variably affected, and there is increased shedding of the neutrophil surface CD16 receptor. These changes indicate that SARS-CoV-2 can directly‚Äîor through infected epithelia‚Äîmodulate neutrophil function in ways that may compromise their capacity to respond appropriately. Furthermore, these modified neutrophils negatively affect lymphocyte populations when co-cultured or via their secreted products: there is measurable reduction in B cell, CD4+ T cell, and CD8+ T cell numbers.

üß´A time‚Äêresolved, large‚Äêscale view of how SARS-CoV-2 infection reshapes host cell signaling by measuring phosphorylation and protein abundance changes in infected cells showed activation of CK2 and p38 MAPK signaling, suppression of mitotic kinases (which leads to cell cycle arrest), and cytoskeletal changes such as the formation of filopodia bearing viral particles. The infection also induced cytokine responses, suggesting the virus triggers innate immune signaling along with hijacking of host cell machinery. By integrating the phosphoproteomics data with drug‚Äêkinase interaction maps, the authors identified several kinases whose inhibition (e.g. of CK2, p38, CDKs, AXL, PIKFYVE) reduced virus replication in vitro

üß´SARS-CoV-2 remodels the cytoskeleton of infected cells to possibly facilitate spread between cells. The authors used high-resolution microscopy to show that infected cells produce more and longer filopodia, that filopodia from different cells form bridges, and that tunneling nanotubes may provide routes for intercellular viral transfer. Viral particles are observed bound to filopodia, within vesicles, and in regions of cell contact, suggesting multiple means by which the virus may move from cell to cell beyond just release into the extracellular space. These structural changes include rearrangements in actin, microtubules, and intermediate filaments, as well as increased ribosomal activity and mitochondrial alterations in infected cells. The 3D reconstructions permitted visualization of ‚Äúviral extrusion‚Äù zones and clusters of filopodial connections at sites of high viral load.

üß´This study uses helium-ion microscopy to uncover alternative intra-cytoplasmic transmission routes for SARS-CoV-2 in infected Vero E6 cells, highlighting tunneling nanotubes (TNT), cell fusion (syncytia), and extracellular vesicles (EV) as key mechanisms. TNT, extending over 40 microns, connect infected cells for direct cytoplasmic exchange, while syncytia form multinucleated clusters via spike protein-induced fusion, and EVs bud from membranes to potentially shuttle viral RNA. By proposing drugs like colchicine, niclosamide, and chloroquine as targeted interventions, the research offers pathophysiological insights and therapeutic avenues, though it notes limitations such as the need for human cell validation and specific viral markers.

üß´SARS-CoV-2 typically infects cells by binding to the ACE2 receptor, which is expressed in many epithelial tissues but is scarcely present in neuronal cells. Yet neurological symptoms are common in acute COVID-19 and long COVID, and viral RNA has been found in brains of some patients. To address how neurons might become infected despite low ACE2, the authors studied co-cultures of permissive Vero E6 epithelial cells (which are infected in the usual way) and non-permissive neuronal cells. They found that SARS-CoV-2 triggers formation of tunneling nanotubes (TNTs) between cells, through which the virus can travel. Inside TNTs, they observed double-membrane vesicles and other structures associated with viral replication (such as nonstructural protein 3, dsRNA), indicating that not only is virus cargo transported but replication-related events occur.

üß´SARS-CoV-2 infection promotes formation of actin-rich filopodia in host cells by activating Cdc42 and engaging actin regulators such as fascin, formins, and the Arp2/3 complex. These filopodia act as ‚Äúhighways‚Äù for virus particles or virus-like particles, which use two modes ‚Äî ‚Äúsurfing‚Äù along the filopodial shaft or ‚Äúgrabbing‚Äù via attachment then retraction ‚Äî to reach entry hotspots on target cells more efficiently than via non-protruded plasma membrane. Disrupting either Cdc42 activity or the actin crosslinker fascin significantly reduces viral entry.

This study assessed documentation of Long COVID (post-COVID-19 condition, PCC) among nearly 389,000 U.S. veterans who tested positive for SARS-CoV-2 during the period October 2021 to January 2023. They found that by 12 months after infection, about 5.3% had the ICD-10 code U09.9 in their medical record, indicating a formal clinical recognition of Long COVID. Patients more likely to have this code were older, female, Hispanic or Latino, had more comorbidities or severe acute COVID infection (hospitalization/ventilation), and had more symptoms during the acute phase. Vaccination (especially booster doses) was associated with lower likelihood of Long COVID documentation. Among those who did receive the U09.9 code, the most frequently documented persistent symptoms included shortness of breath, fatigue or exhaustion, cough, cognitive impairment (‚Äúbrain fog‚Äù), and disturbances in smell or taste. The study also found considerable variation across regions and VA facilities in how often U09.9 was used, with higher usage in places with dedicated Long COVID or PCC clinics.

This study rigorously compared long-term health impacts of hospitalization for COVID-19 versus hospitalization for seasonal influenza, following patients for up to 18 months. It found that COVID-19 survivors face substantially greater risks of death, hospital readmission, and new health problems in a wide array of organ systems. The COVID-19 cohort had higher rates for ~68% of the measured adverse health outcomes, whereas influenza predominantly affected pulmonary outcomes more severely. Importantly, although both diseases show significant long‚Äêterm burdens beyond the immediate acute phase, COVID-19‚Äôs effects are more multi‚Äêsystemic: the disease imposes greater risk of long‚Äêterm damage across cardiovascular, neurological, kidney, metabolic, mental health, and other systems. Influenza remains more exclusively a respiratory illness in this comparison.

Syncytia formation by SARS-CoV-2 increases the virus‚Äôs resistance to interferons and neutralizing antibodies. The study shows that spike protein variants that promote more cell-cell fusion (i.e. more fusogenic S proteins) are better able to withstand interferon treatment in vitro, in airway organ cultures, and in hACE2 transgenic mice. At the same time, higher fusogenicity correlates with reduced neutralization by antibody reagents, meaning that immune pressure favors variants that can fuse infected cells into syncytia. Despite the replication cost of forming syncytia under low immune pressure, the authors suggest that the immune environment in the host selects for fusogenic spike variants. These findings explain why variants with more cell-cell fusion capacity (such as certain Delta or Omicron derivatives) are being selected, and highlight syncytia formation as a mechanism of immune evasion by SARS-CoV-2.

üß´SARS-CoV-2 infection causes distinctive ultrastructural changes in host cells compared to SARS-CoV-1, especially a marked accumulation of lipid droplets in infected cells (both in cultured Vero E6 cells and in type II lung pneumocytes of COVID-19 patients). These lipid droplets often contact mitochondria, and in some cases viral particles are located in or near lipolysosome-like structures, suggesting that lipid metabolic changes are part of the cytopathic effect. Other hallmarks include vacuole formation, mitochondrial swelling/damaged cristae, and general organelle disruption.

üêíSARS-CoV-2 in rhesus macaques can directly infect neurons in the olfactory cortex (and connected regions) within a week of infection, as shown by detection of viral nucleocapsid, spike proteins, and dsRNA. The infection is more pronounced in older and diabetic animals. Although glial cells also show viral markers, neurons carry the bulk of productive infection signals. The virus appears to spread along olfactory neural circuitry, reaching secondary olfactory regions especially in aged animals. Accompanying this neurotropism is strong neuroinflammation and vascular disruption: glial activation, microglial‚Äêmediated synaptic pruning (loss of synaptic markers), myelin degradation, blood vessel and BBB alterations, neutrophil recruitment, among others.

Omicron SARS-CoV-2 variant, which favors entry via clathrin-mediated endocytosis (CME), more strongly induces premature cellular senescence compared to the Delta variant. In lung tissues from deceased patients, Omicron infection was associated with elevated expression of senescence markers such as p16 and p21. Experiments in cultured cells and lung tissue confirm that Omicron but not Delta triggers senescence‚Äêassociated secretory phenotypes (SASP) and related gene expression changes.

This large VA cohort study followed 138,818 people with SARS-CoV-2 infection and nearly 6 million controls for 2 years and evaluated mortality, hospitalization and 80 prespecified post-acute sequelae. Risks for many sequelae declined over time ‚Äî 69% of examined sequelae among nonhospitalized people became not significant by 2 years ‚Äî but a set of pulmonary, coagulation/hematologic, gastrointestinal, musculoskeletal and metabolic outcomes (including new or worsened diabetes) remained elevated at 2 years, and hospitalized patients retained higher mortality and more persistent sequelae

üß´The authors used cultured human nasal epithelial cells to compare common cold viruses with more severe coronaviruses and influenza, finding that mild viruses trigger fast interferon (IFN) responses that mediate viral clearance in the nose. By contrast, lethal coronaviruses (like MERS-CoV) or SARS-CoV-2 employ mechanisms to delay or suppress IFN signaling, leading to persistent replication in nasal epithelium. Elevated temperature (37¬∞C) strengthens IFN responses and helps suppress replication in many viruses. A noteworthy finding is that the Omicron BA.1 variant of SARS-CoV-2 partly behaves like a mild virus in some respects (stronger IFN induction) but resists IFN‚Äêmediated suppression and is not cleared by nasal epithelium, showing reduced temperature sensitivity.

Elderly hospitalized COVID-19 patients with higher levels of bacterial DNA in their blood early in admission had significantly worse outcomes: increased mortality, more severe immune dysregulation (higher neutrophils, lower IFN-Œ±), and a higher likelihood of having diabetes. After controlling for age, frailty, COPD, and other laboratory markers, BB-DNA remained an independent predictor of in-hospital death. The findings support the idea that bacterial translocation‚Äîpossibly from impaired mucosal or intestinal barriers‚Äîcontributes to pathogenesis in severe COVID-19 in older patients, and that BB-DNA may serve as a useful prognostic biomarker.

üß´The paper demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2 spike protein (and heat-inactivated virus) triggers robust mitochondrial and inflammatory responses in human microglial cells. Treated microglia show elevated cytokine and ACE2 expression, activation of HIF-1Œ± and NLRP3 inflammasome, enhanced reactive oxygen species, and morphological changes such as mitochondrial fragmentation and signs of apoptosis. The spike protein alone is sufficient to perturb mitochondrial bioenergetics, raising both basal and maximal oxygen consumption rates.

COVID-19 is frequently associated with smell loss, which has led to speculation that SARS-CoV-2 might trigger inflammation or neurodegenerative changes in the olfactory pathway. To test this, the authors performed post-mortem immunohistochemical studies of the olfactory bulb and tract in 22 COVID-19 patients versus controls (healthy and those with known neurological and neurodegenerative conditions). They assessed microglial activation (via CD68) and presence of characteristic protein-pathologies (phosphorylated Œ±-synuclein, phosphorylated tau, amyloid-Œ≤) particularly in the anterior olfactory nucleus (AON). They found that COVID-19 per se did not show a widespread, COVID-specific elevation in microglial activation or proteinopathy in the olfactory bulb/tract compared to healthy controls. Most increases in neurodegenerative markers (tau, Œ±-synuclein) were observed in individuals already having known disease (e.g. Parkinson‚Äôs, Alzheimer‚Äôs). Also, age was inversely correlated with microglial activation in COVID-19 cases.

SARS-CoV-2 can invade the brain, especially targeting the hypothalamus, via both bloodstream and olfactory (nose-to-brain) routes, infecting neurons such as GnRH neurons and support cells such as tanycytes. Evidence includes detection of viral RNA and spike protein in brain tissues of deceased COVID-19 patients, hormonal profiles in male survivors showing low testosterone without expected gonadotropin feedback, and correlations of these hormonal disruptions with long COVID symptoms like brain fog, metabolic dysregulation, and perhaps sexual/reproductive issues.

The article argues that the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 not only uses ACE2 but also binds heavily sialylated glycan structures on red blood cells, platelets, and endothelial cells, leading to RBC aggregation, microvascular blockage, hypoxia, and vascular damage. These processes help explain a number of severe outcomes in COVID-19, including thrombosis, myocarditis, and multi‚Äêorgan hypoxia. The authors also correlate known risk factors such as age, obesity, and diabetes with higher RBC clotting/aggregability, which may magnify the impact of glycan‚Äêmediated binding. They contrast SARS-CoV-2 with benign human betacoronaviruses that express hemagglutinin esterase (which cleaves sialic acids), suggesting this difference helps explain virulence.

üß´This study demonstrates that SARS-CoV-2 can persist in human cardiac microtissues derived from induced pluripotent stem cells without causing immediate, severe dysfunction, for at least several weeks. However, when these persistently infected tissues are exposed to additional stress (hypoxia/low oxygen), they suffer cardiac functional decline, reactivation of viral activity, elevated ACE2 expression, and damage to vascular network structure.

Hikmet et al. mapped where the human ACE2 protein is present across a wide range of tissues and cell types, combining immunohistochemistry and transcriptomic data. They found that ACE2 is abundantly expressed in non-respiratory tissues (intestine, kidney, heart, reproductive tissues, etc.), while in the respiratory tract the expression is low or limited to few cells in some individuals. These findings suggest that while ACE2 is likely to mediate viral entry, the low abundance in lung/airway tissues might mean other factors (co-receptors, or small specialized cell subsets) are important for SARS-CoV-2 infection of the respiratory tract.

This study reveals that immune cells in the blood (PBMCs) of COVID-19 patients and convalescent individuals harbor diverse intracellular bacterial species, and that the abundance of particular bacteria differs between healthy, infected, and recovered states. By analyzing non-human RNA reads from single-cell sequencing, the authors identified 76 bacterial species overall, of which 16 showed statistically significant differences across health groups. Notably, certain bacteria were enriched in specific immune cell types (memory B cells, na√Øve T cells, Tregs, etc.), and some pathogenic species were especially elevated during acute SARS-CoV-2 infection, hinting at possible interactions between bacterial presence and disease state. The findings suggest that scRNA-seq can go beyond profiling host transcripts to also detect intracellular microbes, potentially opening a window into how such microbes may contribute to immune modulation or disease severity in COVID-19. However, the functional roles of these intracellular microbes remain unclear, and whether they are causative, opportunistic, or simply passengers during infection and recovery is not resolved by this work.

More than one-third of individuals assessed around 11 months after COVID-19 infection exhibited cognitive impairment. Neurocognitive functioning was inversely correlated with LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) blood levels, a potential biomarker of disease severity. Common risk factors for having cognitive problems included older age, male sex, less education, greater disease severity during the acute phase, and specific symptoms like anosmia and dyspnea. Those with impaired cognition also tended to have higher levels of depression, anxiety, post-traumatic stress, and worse general functioning. In this study, from 1,344 screened, only 736 entered the screening phase, and 402 completed the baseline in-depth assessment. Those who stayed were older, more often male, less educated, had more severe COVID-19, and worse MoCA scores than those who dropped out.

This study shows that the capacity of neutrophils to generate NETs when exposed to plasma (NETosis induction) is a sensitive measure that tracks with both acute COVID-19 severity and long COVID, more so than measurement of NET fragments like MPO-DNA complexes. In acute disease, markers of platelet activation and coagulation were elevated, and NETosis induction correlated with these and with how severe/long the disease was. Treatment (dexamethasone) and recovery reduce this induction. In long COVID, even after convalescence, patients maintain a heightened NETosis induction capacity despite having similar levels of NET fragments to other recovered patients.

Vaccination with mRNA COVID-19 vaccines in children aged 5-17 years who are exposed to the Omicron variant is associated with significantly reduced odds of experiencing post-COVID conditions (PCC; symptoms persisting or new one month after infection). Fully vaccinated children had about 34% lower odds of reporting one or more PCC symptoms, 48% lower odds of reporting two or more symptoms, and roughly 47% lower odds of respiratory symptoms compared to unvaccinated children. The analysis controlled for factors like age, health status, etc.

A survey (n ‚âà 276,840 respondents) found that most people who get symptomatic COVID-19 in England recover within 1‚Äì2 weeks. However, a significant fraction continue to have symptoms: about 7.5% report symptoms lasting 12 weeks or more (Long COVID), and ‚âà5.2% still have symptoms at 52 weeks or beyond. Key risk factors for longer symptom persistence include female sex, having pre-existing health conditions, more severe initial illness, earlier infection (wild-type variant), and higher socio-economic deprivation. Conversely, people infected during the Omicron-dominant period were much less likely to have persistent symptoms. Those with long-lasting symptoms report substantially worse quality of life, mental health, and more frequent, burdensome symptoms (such as fatigue, difficulty thinking or concentrating, breathlessness, loss of smell or taste) compared to both recovered COVID cases and people never infected.

This preprint compares immune cell profiles of HIV/AIDS and COVID-19 patients and finds that both diseases cause reductions in several lymphocyte subpopulations. CD4+ T helper cells are similarly depleted in both, but COVID-19 shows much more severe depletion of CD8+ cytotoxic T cells and NK cells. B cell counts are somewhat reduced in both, though not significantly different across the diseases. These distinct patterns suggest that while both viruses lead to lymphopenia, the immune dysregulation in COVID-19 involves more profound suppression of CD8+ T cells and innate immune NK cells, which may contribute to the acute disease severity.

In a cohort of infants born in a low-income region of Brazil, children exposed in utero to maternal SARS-CoV-2 infection (among mothers unvaccinated at the time) were followed for the first year of life and compared with unexposed children. Neurodevelopmental evaluations at multiple time points revealed that about 20% of exposed infants had neurodevelopmental delays by 12 months, compared to under 6% in controls, giving a relative risk of about 3.44. These delays were particularly evident in fine motor and personal-social domains. The pattern of impairment varied over time in exposed infants: high at 4 months, low at 6 months, rising again at 12 months. 137 children were followed for one year: 69 with prenatal exposure (‚Äúexposed group‚Äù, EG) and 68 unexposed (‚Äúcontrol group‚Äù, CG). Neurodevelopment was assessed repeatedly (at 1,2,3,4,5,6,9,12 months) using the Guide for Monitoring Child Development in the Integrated Management of Childhood Illness context. For the exposed group, additional assessments at 4, 6, and 12 months used the Ages & Stages Questionnaire (ASQ-3). Demographics between groups were broadly similar.

Portable HEPA-filter + UV air filtration devices can effectively remove airborne SARS-CoV-2 RNA in a hospital ward environment, especially in less severe settings (non-ICU). When the filters were active, SARS-CoV-2 was not detected in multiple air samples; when inactive, it was again detectible. The ICU, however, showed lower baseline detection and the filtration made less difference in detection of SARS-CoV-2 specifically. Beyond SARS-CoV-2, the filtration systems also reduced the presence of other airborne pathogens (bacteria, fungi, etc.) in both settings.

Two infant cases are described where maternal COVID-19 infection in the second trimester, despite maternal recovery before delivery and negative neonatal PCR tests, was followed by serious neurologic injury in the newborns: seizures, developmental delay, microcephaly, brain tissue atrophy. Examination of the placentas showed SARS-CoV-2 viral proteins, vascular malperfusion, elevated inflammatory and oxidative stress markers, and reduced hCG. In one fatal case, SARS-CoV-2 proteins were also found in the infant‚Äôs brain at autopsy, suggesting possible direct brain infection. The study suggests that in utero exposure to SARS-CoV-2 can lead to brain injury via placental inflammation and dysfunction, even in absence of vertical transmission detectable at birth, and that current fetal monitoring may miss these harms.

During acute COVID-19 illness, patients hospitalized with neurological complications show elevated biomarkers of neuroglial damage (NfL, GFAP, tTau, UCH-L1), along with elevated cytokines and the presence of autoantibodies, particularly in those with altered consciousness. This suggests that both innate and adaptive immune dysregulation are involved in the brain injury that occurs in COVID-19. The study identifies specific inflammatory mediators (e.g. IL-6, IL-12p40, HGF, CCL2, IL-1RA) that correlate with the severity of neurological involvement. Autoantibodies against neuronal/glial proteins are more frequent among those with neurological symptoms. Beyond the acute phase, even after systemic inflammation and autoantibody levels decline, markers of brain injury (notably NfL and GFAP) remain elevated in people who had neurological complications. This indicates that some forms of brain injury in COVID-19 may be long-lasting or slow to resolve, despite resolution of overt inflammation.

This study followed over 2,200 adult patients with COVID-19 in recovery clinics in British Columbia, examining their kidney function, primarily through eGFR, over 12 months from about 3 months post infection. While roughly half maintained ‚Äúnormal‚Äù kidney filtration rates, there was on average a decline of ~3 mL/min/1.73 m¬≤ over that year‚Äîabout a 3.4% decrease from baseline. Only a small minority (<5%) had severely reduced kidney function. Urine protein levels (via UACR) were also part of the analyses, though the most pronounced findings concerned the eGFR declines.

The PROTECT study of over 3,100 UK adults aged 50+ found that during the COVID-19 pandemic there was a measurable acceleration of decline in working memory and executive function compared with pre-pandemic trajectories, with the first pandemic year showing the biggest drop. Some of the decline in working memory persisted into the second pandemic year. Subgroups‚Äîpeople with mild cognitive impairment and those who had COVID-19‚Äîhad larger declines. Self-reported lifestyle and psychosocial factors such as reduced physical activity, increased alcohol consumption, depression, and loneliness were associated with worse cognitive outcomes. Whether or not participants had had COVID-19 was based on self-report rather than confirmed PCR/antibody testing.

Long COVID patients who experience post-exertional malaise show substantially reduced exercise capacity compared to recovered controls, largely due to impairments in skeletal muscle rather than cardiovascular or purely ventilatory limitations. Their muscles have more fatigue-prone, glycolytic fibers, smaller oxidative fibers, and reduced mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation. After an exercise challenge, these impairments worsen: metabolic disturbances intensify, muscle damage increases, immune cell infiltration occurs, and amyloid‚Äêcontaining deposits accumulate in muscle tissue. Importantly, the study did not find elevated levels of SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein in skeletal muscle of Long COVID patients relative to controls, before or after PEM induction, implying that viral persistence (at least of that protein in muscle) is not the main driver of these muscle deficits.

People who had received the XBB.1.5-adapted vaccine had substantially lower odds of testing positive among those seeking care, with adjusted odds ratios around 0.4 for hospitalization, ED/urgent care, and outpatient settings‚Äîmeaning roughly 60% or so lower risk compared to those who did not have the adapted vaccine. Older vaccine versions (non-XBB.1.5) provided much less protection in comparison.

Coronaviruses like the mouse hepatitis virus can infect the central nervous system (CNS) and establish both acute and persistent infection. In acute infection, virus‚Äêspecific T cells are crucial: CD8‚Å∫ T cells kill infected microglia and astrocytes, while interferon-Œ≥ is required to suppress virus in oligodendrocytes. To avoid excessive damage in CNS tissue, after the acute phase, cytolytic T cell functions are downregulated and virus‚Äêspecific antibody responses in the CNS increase. These antibodies are necessary to prevent reappearance of infectious virus; even during persistence, the virus remains replication competent and can resurface without antibody control.

üêÅIn rats, RSV reinfection caused worse kidney injury than primary infection, with higher protein leakage in urine, lower serum albumin, and structural glomerular damage (podocyte effacement, mesangial proliferation). These effects were dose-dependent and timing-dependent, peaking when the reinfection came 14 days after the first exposure. Mechanistically, reinfection skewed immunity: dendritic cells matured, CD8 T cells increased, the CD4/CD8 ratio decreased, and IL-6/IL-17 surged. RSV F protein persisted in glomeruli up to day 56, implying direct viral involvement in addition to immune-mediated injury. Overall, RSV can directly and indirectly worsen renal damage during reinfection.

More than half (56%) of adults in a Los Angeles County cohort who seroconverted during the Omicron wave were unaware that they had been infected with SARS-CoV-2. Among those unaware, only a small proportion had symptoms, which they often attributed to non-COVID causes. Awareness was somewhat greater among younger individuals, males, and healthcare workers. The study highlights that many Omicron infections go undetected by individuals themselves, even among vaccinated populations.

17 Medical students who had mild COVID-19 at least six months earlier were compared to 18 non-infected peers to look for long-term cognitive effects. While overall attention and combined visual + auditory working memory scores were similar between the two groups, those who had COVID-19 underperformed significantly on auditory working memory tasks, but not on visual working memory.

This study followed 29 hospitalized COVID-19 patients for one year and tested many immune markers during the acute infection to see which might predict development of long COVID. Of all the measures tested ‚Äî including cytokines, T cell activation, exhaustion, NK/monocyte profiles ‚Äî the only strong predictor was the degree of apoptosis (programmed cell death) in CD4‚Å∫ helper T cells during the acute phase: people with higher levels were significantly more likely to report long COVID one year later.The findings suggest that early loss of CD4‚Å∫ T cells may set the stage for downstream problems (viral persistence, latent virus reactivation, immune dysregulation, etc.) that contribute to long COVID.

The authors conclude that azvudine has satisfactory effectiveness and acceptable safety in this older cohort, suggesting it could be considered a treatment option for elderly patients with mild to moderate COVID-19. From treatment initiation to nucleic acid negative (NANC) conversion, the median was 8 days for azvudine vs 9 days for nirmatrelvir/ritonavir. Those on azvudine had a median time from symptom onset to NANC of 14 days, compared to 15 days for nirmatrelvir/ritonavir, and 19 days for standard of care. However, being observational and with a small sample size, the findings would need confirmation in larger or randomized studies.

This study examined 16 individuals experiencing long-term fatigue, weakness, or myalgia 5 to 14 months after a COVID-19 infection of mild to moderate severity. Through electromyographic testing and detailed examination of muscle biopsies (light and electron microscopy), the authors found that a large proportion of patients exhibit structural muscle changes: atrophy, signs of fiber regeneration, mitochondrial dysfunction (loss of COX activity, abnormal cristae, subsarcolemmal mitochondrial accumulation), inflammation involving T cells and HLA-ABC expression, and significant capillary injury including alterations in the basal lamina and capillary cells. These findings indicate that skeletal muscle pathology ‚Äî a myopathy ‚Äî is likely a significant contributor to fatigue in long COVID. The involvement of mitochondrial impairment and microvascular damage suggests that reduced energy supply and oxygen/nutrient delivery play a role.

In this 2-year follow-up of COVID-19 cases from early 2020 in Korea, over 60% of participants who completed all follow-ups continued to report at least one symptom of long COVID, most commonly fatigue, memory issues, concentration difficulties, and insomnia. Although overall quality of life improved over time, a substantial proportion still suffered from anxiety or depression even after two years post-infection. Despite high vaccine uptake after infection (most had at least two doses), neither vaccination status nor number of doses showed a statistically meaningful reduction in neuropsychiatric long COVID symptoms at 24 months.

This study followed 351 individuals who were hospitalized with COVID-19 and assessed them about a year later, comparing them to nearly 3,000 matched controls. It found that cognitive deficits were still present at 1 year, affecting multiple cognitive domains (not just memory or executive function), and these deficits occurred even in people who had not been diagnosed with neurological complications during their acute COVID-19 illness. Biomarker tests revealed elevated levels of brain injury markers (such as GFAP and NfL), and MRI scans showed reduced grey matter volume in key brain regions (notably the anterior cingulate cortex). The severity of the initial illness, having had encephalopathy, and psychiatric symptoms post-COVID were associated with worse outcomes. Although there was some improvement over time in the subset with longitudinal data, recovery seemed only partial and appeared to plateau.

A vaccinated adult male in Brazil, who had no underlying health conditions, first contracted an Omicron BA.1.1 infection. Sixteen days after the first infection was detected, he acquired a second distinct infection with Omicron BA.2, confirmed by RT-qPCR and genetic sequencing. Both infections produced symptoms lasting about a week, with a return to daily activities in between.

This cross-sectional study examined endoscopic biopsies from 249 patients with a prior PCR-confirmed COVID-19 infection. Using immunohistochemistry, SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid proteins were detected in 30.5% of cases, with significantly higher prevalence in upper GI tract biopsies than in lower GI samples. Viral persistence was not linked to vaccination status, number of infections, or time since the last infection. Instead, smoking and diabetes were identified as major risk factors for persistent gut infection.

Long COVID (LC) is associated with lasting immune changes: eight months after acute SARS-CoV-2 infection, people with LC show evidence of ongoing systemic inflammation, immune cell subset perturbations, and elevated antibody levels compared to people who have fully recovered. Specifically, CD4+ T cell populations in LC are more likely to express markers that allow them to home to inflamed tissues, and SARS-CoV-2-specific CD8+ T cells show exhaustion signatures. There is also a miscoordination between T-cell and B-cell (antibody) responses in LC, suggesting that though both adaptive arms are active, they are not working in a well-orchestrated way. These immune irregularities may underlie the persistent symptoms seen in LC ‚Äî such as fatigue, cognitive issues, sleep disturbances ‚Äî perhaps driven by ongoing antigen exposure or dysregulated immune signaling. The study‚Äôs depth (multi-omics) provides pieces of a mechanism: immune dysregulation, chronic inflammation, and maladapted adaptive immunity. However, due to sample size and diversity among LC patients, more work is needed (including studying tissues, not just blood) to fully map causation and heterogeneity.

Long COVID patients, prior to vaccination, display two distinct types of adaptive immune responses. One group (LC+) is seropositive and shows strong, coordinated antibody and CD4+ T cell responses to SARS-CoV-2 (and breadth comparable to recovered people), while the other (LC‚àí) is seronegative by standard assays, with low or undetectable antibody responses and only partially detectable T cell responses even with more sensitive assays. Both groups report persistent symptoms of similar severity, indicating that immune response strength or detectability does not map straightforwardly onto symptom burden. These findings suggest that long COVID is not a single immunological state but may have (at least) two subtypes: one where the immune system has mounted a strong antiviral adaptive response but symptoms persist (potentially via immunopathology or chronic antigen exposure), and another where the antiviral response is weak, which might allow antigen persistence or inadequate clearance.

Kloc et al. propose that nicotine might modulate lung macrophage responses via nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (notably Œ±7 nAChR) to suppress excessive pro-inflammatory cytokine release (a cytokine storm) in COVID-19, offering a mechanistic hypothesis for observed lower-than-expected rates of smokers among severe COVID-19 cases. They suggest that nicotine stimulation of cholinergic pathways in macrophages could tip the balance toward controlled inflammation rather than runaway immune activation. They emphasize that their suggestion is theoretical, not clinical advice, and that many variables (dose, timing, receptor expression, comorbidities) complicate the idea.

üêÅThe study shows that mice lacking adaptive immune cells (B and T lymphocytes) infected with mouse-adapted SARS-CoV-2 do not lose weight and exhibit minimal lung inflammation and cytokine release, despite supporting viral replication. Thus, while adaptive immunity is required to clear the virus, its activation also drives much of the tissue pathology associated with COVID-19.

This clinical trial in critically ill COVID-19 patients under mechanical ventilation tested whether nicotine patches might reduce mortality or improve recovery, hypothesizing that nicotine‚Äôs interaction with the nicotinic cholinergic system could modulate inflammation or ACE2 expression. However, the study found no significant effects ‚Äî 28-day mortality was the same in nicotine and placebo arms (28% each), and secondary endpoints (ventilator-free days, extubation timing, organ failure support) also showed no advantage. Nicotine was well tolerated with few adverse events, but conferred no clinical benefit.

SARS-CoV-2 and HIV-1 share some superficial similarities‚Äîthey are both enveloped, positive single-stranded RNA viruses with spike glycoproteins mediating entry‚Äîbut differ substantially in their replication cycles, host interactions, and immune evasion strategies. SARS-CoV-2 does not integrate into the host genome, replicates in the cytoplasm with proofreading, and uses ACE2 (plus proteases) for cell entry, leading to a relatively faster replication cycle. In contrast, HIV-1 reverse-transcribes its RNA, integrates into host DNA, uses CD4 plus co-receptors for entry, has high error rates (hence high diversity), and establishes latent infection, which makes eradication extremely difficult. Because of these mechanistic differences, their interactions with the immune system diverge: HIV-1‚Äôs dense glycan shield, latent reservoirs, and high mutation rate impede development of broadly neutralizing antibodies, while SARS-CoV-2 tends to be more ‚Äúopen‚Äù to vaccine-elicited neutralizing immune responses, despite also evolving escape variants.

In a large national cohort of Brazilian children hospitalized with severe acute respiratory infection, this study compared in-hospital mortality across SARS-CoV-2 and seasonal respiratory viruses. SARS-CoV-2 was the predominant virus and carried the highest 30-day fatality risk (~6.5 %) compared with influenza, RSV, adenovirus, other viruses, or coinfections. After adjusting for competing risks, SARS-CoV-2 positivity was associated with a roughly threefold higher hazard of death relative to SARS-CoV-2‚Äìnegative cases. Across viral etiologies, lower oxygen saturation at admission, presence of comorbidities, and being hospitalized in the North or Northeast regions of Brazil were independent predictors of death.

This pilot study provides evidence that SARS-CoV-2 actively replicates in the gut of nearly half of hospitalized COVID-19 patients, including those without gastrointestinal symptoms. From 15 hospitalized COVID-19 patients, the authors detected active viral transcription in 7 (47%) patients, even in the absence of GI symptoms. Viral transcriptional signatures persisted in stool for days after clearance from the respiratory tract, suggesting prolonged quiescent GI infection and a potential role in fecal‚Äìoral transmission. Patients with high fecal viral activity had stool microbiota enriched in opportunistic pathogens (Collinsella aerofaciens, Collinsella tanakaei, Streptococcus infantis, Morganella morganii) and showed increased bacterial functional capacity for nucleotide, amino acid biosynthesis, and glycolysis. In contrast, those with low or no viral activity had more short-chain fatty acid‚Äìproducing bacteria (Parabacteroides merdae, Bacteroides stercoris, Alistipes onderdonkii, Lachnospiraceae species), which are linked to immune regulation.

Diorio et al. show that children hospitalized with SARS-CoV-2 infection, including those with minimal symptoms, frequently have elevated levels of the complement activation biomarker sC5b9 compared to healthy controls, and many meet clinical criteria for thrombotic microangiopathy (TMA). The elevation in sC5b9 was seen across minimal, severe COVID-19, and MIS-C groups, and correlated with markers of renal stress (e.g. creatinine).

Analyzing over 2.17 million SARS-CoV-2 raw-read datasets with a unified workflow, the study estimates co-infection in ~0.35% of cases and uses two complementary methods to detect intra-host recombination. Co-infections tracked periods of variant co-circulation (especially Delta‚ÄìOmicron BA.1), and recombination signals were most detectable where lineage-defining mutations are dense. Because artefacts (PCR chimeras, primer bias, contamination) can masquerade as recombinants, the authors lay out practical safeguards (including a ~0.1 recombinant-read threshold) and show hotspots at gene boundaries plus three intergenic hotspots for Delta‚ÄìOmicron BA.1.

This study followed 113 COVID-19 patients up to one year post-infection (plus healthy controls) to investigate why some develop Long COVID while others recover. Long COVID is associated with a sustained abnormal activation of the complement system (both classical and alternative pathways) that doesn‚Äôt return to baseline, unlike in people who recover. In addition, those with active Long COVID show elevated markers of blood cell damage, platelet activation, and monocyte-platelet interactions, all hinting at ongoing inflammation and coagulation (thromboinflammation). The study also found that higher antibody levels against herpesviruses might be contributing to triggering the classical complement pathway. The results point to specific protein signatures in blood that could serve as biomarkers to distinguish Long COVID patients from recovered ones, and suggest that complement and coagulation pathways are potential therapeutic targets.

The authors differentiated dopaminergic (DA) neurons from human pluripotent stem cells (hPSCs), exposed them to SARS-CoV-2, and assessed infection, transcriptional changes, and cell state. They observed that only a minority (~5 %) of DA neurons become infected, but that is sufficient to trigger downstream senescence and inflammation. The authors validated this phenomenon using postmortem human substantia nigra tissue from COVID-19 patients, finding SARS-CoV-2 transcripts (though at low levels) and an inflammatory/senescence signature, along with reduced numbers of neuromelanin-positive and tyrosine-hydroxylase-positive DA neurons in severely affected patients. They also performed a drug screen and identified FDA-approved drugs (riluzole, metformin, imatinib) that can reduce viral infection and rescue the senescence phenotype in DA neurons.

This medRxiv preprint compares antibody subclass responses after repeated mRNA versus protein-based COVID-19 vaccination. Consistent with prior observations, repeated mRNA vaccination is associated with higher proportions of Spike-specific IgG4 and lower Fc-effector surrogates (markers tied to ADCP/ADCC/ADCD). Repeated dosing with Novavax (protein subunit), by contrast, did not show notable IgG4 increases and instead boosted IgG3, a subclass associated with stronger FcŒ≥RIIIa binding and historically linked to potent neutralization.

This study examined 97 non-hospitalized individuals recovering from mild COVID-19 (about 2‚Äì3 months post-infection) without psychiatric comorbidities, comparing them to 77 matched controls. Clinically, many post-COVID participants reported memory loss (36 %), fatigue (31 %), headache (29 %), somnolence (35 %), and showed deficits on tests of verbal fluency and memory (e.g. ~21 % had impaired phonemic verbal fluency). In DTI analyses, the post-COVID group showed higher axial diffusivity (AD) in certain white matter tracts compared to controls (suggesting microstructural white matter alteration), though no differences were found in fractional anisotropy (FA), mean diffusivity (MD), or radial diffusivity (RD). In rs-fMRI of the default mode network (posterior cingulate seed), there were no significant group differences in connectivity after correction, and no strong correlations between imaging metrics and cognitive scores or fatigue/sleepiness measures.

Persistent complement activation and its crosstalk with coagulation and endothelial injury may underlie many features of Long COVID, such as microvascular damage, chronic inflammation, and prolonged immune activation. Ruf emphasizes that complement dysregulation can perpetuate tissue injury long after viral clearance, creating a feedback loop of immune/coagulation damage.

The authors characterize antibodies to the SARS-CoV-2 membrane (M) protein in infected individuals, showing that although such antibodies fail to neutralize the virus, they can trigger Fc-dependent effector functions (notably ADCC) by engaging Fc receptor‚Äìbearing cells. In particular, M-directed antibodies from critically ill patients exhibited stronger activation of cytotoxic responses compared to antibodies from those with milder disease. In a clinical correlation analysis, elevated anti-M IgG levels were strongly associated with lung injury, outperforming associations seen with anti-S or anti-N antibodies.

The study used whole-blood digital transcriptomics in a GP-based cohort (48 LC, 12 matched controls; up to 39-month follow-up) and found systemic SARS-CoV-2 RNA persistence in a large subset of Long COVID patients‚Äîincluding antisense viral RNA consistent with ongoing replication. A two-gene classifier (host FYN + viral antisense RNA) discriminated LC from controls with ~94% AUC and ~94%/92% sensitivity/specificity. Host-side signals (elevated ACE2/TMPRSS2, DPP4/FURIN, memory-B and platelet transcripts) and a depressed immunometabolism score (inversely related to viral load) offered mechanistic links to LC biology and symptoms; platelet signatures tracked with viral load, and higher viral RNA associated with worse emotional scores. More COVID-19 vaccine doses associated with lower odds of high viral RNA.

Thao et al. (2020) develop a yeast-based synthetic genomics system for rapid assembly and rescue of full-length RNA virus genomes, including SARS-CoV-2. By amplifying overlapping viral DNA fragments, co-transforming them into yeast for in vivo recombination into a yeast artificial chromosome, and using T7 polymerase‚Äìmediated in vitro transcription, the authors were able to reconstitute infectious virus in cell culture. They demonstrate this method‚Äôs effectiveness with SARS-CoV-2 and other RNA virus families, and show that recombinant viruses replicate with kinetics similar to isolates and that the genomic constructs are stable over yeast passages. This platform reduces the delay between sequence release and functional virus generation, enabling faster experimental characterization of emerging variants or engineered modifications (e.g. reporter insertions), which is especially valuable during outbreak response. The authors propose this as a general, rapid reverse-genetics tool for RNA viruses, facilitating downstream studies (e.g. pathogenesis, antiviral testing, vaccine design).

The preprint presents evidence that binding of the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein (especially from Omicron subvariants) to the ACE2 receptor is temperature dependent, with higher affinity at warmer temperatures (such as those in the nasal/upper airway environment). They show that some mutations in the Omicron spike further enhance this temperature sensitivity, and that this enhanced binding correlates with greater infectivity in respiratory epithelial model systems. These findings support the idea that the transmission advantage of recent Omicron lineages may in part stem from an improved ability to bind ACE2 under physiological temperatures encountered in the upper respiratory tract.

In a cohort of hospital employees with predominantly mild acute COVID-19, about 50% reported ongoing symptoms 90 days or more after infection, indicating a substantial burden of long COVID even in non-hospitalized individuals. The most persistent symptoms varied, and symptom clusters and temporal patterns were analyzed to better understand their co-occurrence and evolution. Predictors of prolonged symptom duration included female gender, a greater number of initial symptoms, and presence of comorbid conditions.

COVID-19 infection is associated with a substantially increased short-term risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) events and death: within 21 days of diagnosis, individuals with COVID-19 had hazard ratios of ~4 to 5 for new CVD and ~67 to 81 for all-cause mortality compared to matched controls. Even after surviving the acute phase, COVID-19 patients remained at elevated long-term risk: over 18 months, the risk of new cardiovascular events remained ~30‚Äì40% higher (HR ~1.3‚Äì1.4), and mortality ~4- to 5-fold higher than in non-infected controls.

This study of ~13,600 adults over 12 months demonstrates that individuals hospitalized with COVID-19 (i.e. ‚Äúsevere‚Äù cases) face a significantly elevated risk of all-cause mortality in the following year compared both to noninfected individuals and those with mild/moderate infection. The hazard ratio for 12-month mortality was ~2.5 versus COVID-negative and ~1.9 versus mild cases, even after adjusting for age, sex, race, and comorbidities. Importantly, most of the post-acute deaths (‚âà 80 %) were from causes other than respiratory or cardiovascular disease, implying a broader, systemic impact of severe COVID-19.

Merad et al. provide a sweeping review of COVID-19 immunology, synthesizing what has been learned about how innate and adaptive immune responses respond to SARS-CoV-2 infection. They emphasize that a properly timed and regulated immune response is crucial: insufficient early antiviral defense (e.g. interferon) or overactive inflammation can both lead to worse outcomes. The review also explores how pathological immune activation (cytokine storms, complement, endothelial damage) contributes to severe disease. The article also considers post-acute and chronic consequences of COVID-19, discussing how persistent immune activation, dysregulation, or even residual viral persistence may underlie long COVID.

Long COVID may include a significant autonomic dysfunction component, resulting in symptoms of orthostatic intolerance (such as dizziness, palpitations, fatigue) and impaired regulation of blood pressure and heart rate. Dani et al. outline the rationale that SARS-CoV-2 or the consequent immune response might damage autonomic neural circuits, endothelial support, or reflex arcs, giving rise to a dysregulated autonomic state. They argue that clinicians should recognize and evaluate for autonomic dysfunction in post-COVID patients, and provide a framework of supportive treatments (e.g. increased fluids/salt, compression, graded activity) while noting that stronger evidence is needed.

Pretorius et al. demonstrate that individuals with Long COVID harbor persistent amyloid microclots in their plasma, which resist breakdown by standard fibrinolytic processes. Compared to controls, these microclots trap elevated levels of coagulation and inflammatory proteins ‚Äî especially Œ±‚ÇÇ-antiplasmin, fibrinogen chains, and Serum Amyloid A ‚Äî suggesting a dysregulated balance between clot formation and clot dissolution in Long COVID. These findings suggest that microvascular obstruction from persistent, fibrinolysis‚Äêresistant microclots may contribute to Long COVID symptoms, and the authors propose that targeted anti‚Äêclotting or fibrinolytic therapies might help mitigate this phenomenon.

194 people with Long COVID (PCC) show markedly slower cognitive processing than both 63 people who had COVID but did not develop long-term symptoms, and 113 uninfected controls. Using simple reaction time and vigilance tasks, the researchers found that over half of PCC participants responded more than two standard deviations slower than controls, even in a brief 30-second task. This slowing remained significant after adjusting for fatigue, depression, anxiety, sleep issues, or PTSD, suggesting it reflects a core cognitive impairment rather than secondary symptoms.

Vanderboom et al. applied high-resolution proteomics and phosphoproteomics to nasopharyngeal swabs from SARS-CoV-2‚Äìinfected and uninfected individuals, identifying over 7,500 proteins. They found a strong upregulation of interferon-driven antiviral signaling (e.g. MX1, ISG15, STAT1, RIG-I, CXCL10) accompanied by downregulation of proteasome components, E3 ubiquitin ligases, and translational machinery. Phosphoproteomic analysis revealed altered phosphorylation in antiviral effectors and ciliary proteins (CEP131, CFAP57), and diminished phosphorylation of AKT and PKC family kinases.

Scardua-Silva et al. performed a cross-sectional case‚Äìcontrol study comparing 97 individuals who had experienced mild (non-hospitalized) COVID-19 (median ~79 days after diagnosis) with 77 matched healthy controls. The participants were selected to exclude those with current or prior anxiety or depression. The COVID group reported higher rates of fatigue (83 %), memory complaints, and reduced performance on verbal fluency and logical memory tasks. Using diffusion tensor imaging, the authors detected increased axial diffusivity in white matter tracts compared to healthy controls, indicating possible microstructural changes, while resting-state connectivity did not show significant alterations after correction.

Prior infection with the common cold coronavirus OC43 can prime T cells that recognize SARS-CoV-2. In human-HLA transgenic mice, this pre-exposure lowered SARS-CoV-2 lung virus levels and disease, and the protection depended in part on CD4‚Å∫ T cells. A key cross-reactive CD8‚Å∫ response targeted a conserved nucleocapsid epitope; cross-reactive anti-spike antibodies were not detected.

üß´Murata et al. developed a 3D human cardiac microtissue (human induced pluripotent stem cell-derived) platform to model persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection, finding that mild infection can persist for at least a month with minimal immediate functional impairment. Under simulated ischemic (hypoxic) stress, however, the tissues show viral reactivation, upregulation of ACE2 and spike protein, functional decline, and vascular disruption. They also measured inflammatory cytokines (IL-6, TNF-Œ±, IL-1Œ≤) and found elevation in the culture supernatants after hypoxia/reperfusion stress. Their findings support a scenario where latent or chronic SARS-CoV-2 in the heart might act as a ‚Äútime bomb,‚Äù triggering overt cardiac injury under additional stress.

This BMJ clinical review outlines how to recognise and manage cognitive dysfunction after covid-19 in primary care. Cognitive complaints‚Äîcommonly memory, attention and concentration problems‚Äîare frequent in long covid, fluctuate over time and can substantially limit daily life and work. Many patients improve within a year, but persistence beyond 12 months predicts slower recovery. Evidence on mechanisms is still mixed and heterogeneous. The article recommends a structured assessment: document symptom pattern and functional impact, exclude alternative explanations and red flags, and recognise that routine screens may miss executive-function deficits. Management is supportive‚Äîeducation, pacing and energy management, sleep optimisation, vocational accommodations, cognitive rehab/compensatory strategies, and addressing comorbidities‚Äîwhile acknowledging the absence of proven disease-specific pharmacologic treatments.

Mutations in the SARS-CoV-2 N gene (specifically in the region targeted by the N1 qPCR probe) can lead to significant underestimation of viral RNA levels in wastewater surveillance using RT-qPCR. The authors combine mutation detection in field wastewater samples over 2021‚Äì2022 with controlled experiments using mutant synthetic templates to show that even a single nucleotide change in the probe binding region can reduce assay sensitivity. As a result, N1 results can be depressed relative to N2, particularly during later Omicron waves when such mutations became common. The authors argue that reliance on a single qPCR target is risky in the face of viral evolution. They recommend multiplexing assays, ongoing assay validation, and quality control protocols to ensure wastewater surveillance remains accurate even as SARS-CoV-2 variants emerge and mutate.

Osiaevi et al. (2024) propose that capillary rarefication ‚Äî a permanent or long-lasting reduction in capillary density ‚Äî may be a contributing mechanism to symptoms in Long COVID. The editorial draws on prior evidence of microvascular and endothelial damage after SARS-CoV-2 infection, and suggests that when capillary networks are diminished, tissues receive less oxygen and nutrients, aggravating fatigue, muscle weakness, and organ dysfunction that characterize Long COVID. They also emphasize that microvascular injury, impaired angiogenesis, and endothelial dysfunction could drive this capillary loss, and recommend further research into interventions aimed at reversing or compensating for microvascular deficits.

üêÅMany viral infections are linked to neurological complications, but the culprit isn‚Äôt always the virus itself. In Zika-infected mice, neurological disease tracked with NKG2D‚Å∫ CD8‚Å∫ T-cell infiltration into the brain, not with how much virus was present. Blocking these CD8‚Å∫ cells or their NKG2D receptor prevented paralysis, while cytokine stimulation (IL-12/18) lowered viral load but worsened neurological symptoms, indicating antigen-independent ‚Äúbystander‚Äù cytotoxicity as the damaging mechanism. Thus, CD8‚Å∫ T cells acting through NKG2D can drive neuropathology during viral infection, making this pathway a promising therapeutic target.

This review compares influenza and SARS-CoV-2 in the respiratory tract, examining how viral tropism, host immune responses, and tissue damage intersect to produce a spectrum of disease severities. While the host immune response is essential for clearance, it can also drive pathology, particularly when dysregulated. Influenza binds to sialic acids on epithelial cells (mostly upper airway), with avian vs. human adaptation defined by Œ±2,3 vs. Œ±2,6 linkages. SARS-CoV-2 binds to ACE2 (with TMPRSS2 and other proteases assisting entry), expressed in subsets of ciliated cells, type II alveolar cells, and other epithelia. This narrower receptor distribution partly explains distinct tissue targets and pathogenesis. Influenza tends to infect upper respiratory tract cells more readily (though severe strains can descend into alveoli). SARS-CoV-2 can infect both upper and lower respiratory tract, with significant consequences in alveolar regions and vascular compartments ‚Äî this contributes to severe pneumonia and ARDS-like pathology. Influenza has a short incubation period (1‚Äì2 days) and rapid onset of symptoms, so transmission peaks around or after symptom onset. SARS-CoV-2 has a longer incubation (4‚Äì6 days) and allows pre-symptomatic transmission, which has major implications for pandemic spread. Influenza typically induces a brisk interferon response, sometimes protective but also damaging if excessive. SARS-CoV-2 often shows a blunted or delayed interferon response, with later excessive inflammation (e.g., cytokine storm) contributing to pathology. Influenza usually causes epithelial necrosis and damage in conducting airways, with repair via proliferation of basal and alveolar type II cells. SARS-CoV-2 often involves diffuse alveolar damage, endothelial injury, microvascular thrombosis, and sometimes long-lasting epithelial dysplasia or fibrosis ‚Äî more extensive and protracted repair failure than typical influenza.

In older adults (age 60+), SARS-CoV-2 infection appears to be temporally associated with an elevated risk of developing new-onset dementia, based on a meta-analysis of observational studies. The stronger associations are observed at longer follow-up intervals (around one year), and more severe COVID-19 may further increase the risk compared to milder cases. The authors note, however, that this increased risk is not clearly higher than risks seen after other respiratory infections like influenza. Because the studies included vary greatly in their design, dementia definitions, follow-up durations, and adjustment covariates the conclusions should be interpreted cautiously.

This matched cohort leveraged pre-infection lung tests to quantify how mild COVID-19 alters lung function over time. Compared with uninfected controls, cases showed a significant additional decline in forced expiratory volume in 1 second from before infection to ~6 months after; forced vital capacity behaved similarly. Between 6 and 24 months, the excess decline attenuated and was not significant, and diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide improved modestly, but overall the data suggest incomplete recovery two years after a mild infection.

In a US EHR study of 62k people with COVID-19, new psychiatric diagnoses in the 14‚Äì90 days after infection were more common than after several other acute health events, especially for anxiety, insomnia, and (in older adults) dementia. About 18% had any psychiatric diagnosis and ~6% had a first-ever psychiatric diagnosis in that window. People with a psychiatric diagnosis in the prior year were also more likely to receive a COVID-19 diagnosis (RR‚âà1.65), even after matching on known medical risks‚Äîimplying a bidirectional association between COVID-19 and psychiatric conditions, while not proving causality.

BMJ‚Äôs practice update equips primary care with a structured approach to long covid: recognise common symptom clusters; take a careful history (including post-exertional worsening); rule out alternative causes; and address symptoms with personalised, supportive care. Practical tips include conservative return-to-activity using pacing; screening for autonomic problems; targeted respiratory and sleep management; and attention to mental health, work/benefits, and caregiver needs. Clear referral thresholds and an at-a-glance infographic support day-to-day decisions. The article stresses that evidence for disease-modifying treatments remains limited; most care is symptomatic and rehabilitative, ideally delivered via integrated, community-based services. It highlights the importance of consistent terminology and patient-centred communication, and signposts resources for both clinicians and patients.

Using a large, nationally reweighted U.S. online survey of adults with prior test-confirmed COVID-19, the authors estimate that ~14% had symptoms persisting ‚â•2 months, translating to ~1.7% of U.S. adults at the study timepoint. Older age (above 40) and female sex were linked to higher odds, while higher education, higher income, and living in urban areas were linked to lower odds. Risk appeared lower for infections during Epsilon and Omicron predominance versus ancestral-strain periods, and prior completion of a primary vaccination series was associated with reduced odds of long COVID. Commonly reported symptoms included fatigue, loss of smell, brain fog, memory problems, and sleep disruption.

This human SARS-CoV-2 challenge in previously uninfected adults mapped early immune dynamics in the nose and blood. About half became infected. Interferon-related mediators surged early, T cells (CD4‚Å∫/CD8‚Å∫) activated quickly with proliferative phenotypes, and antibodies emerged around day 10; nasal antibodies plateaued earlier than systemic ones. Statistical modeling linked stronger CD8‚Å∫ T-cell responses and rapid mucosal IgA to better viral control, pointing to these as desirable targets for interventions aimed at reducing viral replication and transmission.

This MR study by Li et al. investigated whether genetic predisposition to COVID-19 (severe disease, hospitalization, or infection) could causally influence the risk of developing various cancers. The authors found ‚Äúsuggestive‚Äù evidence that higher liability to severe COVID-19 is associated with increased risks of cancers such as HER2-positive breast cancer, esophageal cancer, colorectal cancer, stomach cancer, and colon cancer; and that liability to infection may be associated with stomach cancer risk. However, these associations were not definitive. The authors addressed pleiotropy and heterogeneity, but the magnitude of the associations is small, and the study is limited by MR assumptions, population stratification, and the possibility that the genetic instruments may act through pleiotropic pathways.

Lung cancer and COVID-19 share a number of dysregulated genes, particularly 36 genes whose expression is altered in both disease contexts. These genes cluster in biological processes tied to cell cycle control, DNA repair, immune modulation, and cellular stress responses. Through network analyses, the authors highlight several genes (hub nodes) as potential key mediators, and explore candidate drug compounds that might target these genes or their pathways. Overall, the study suggests that COVID-19 may aggravate lung cancer progression via shared molecular mechanisms, and that some of these molecules may be actionable in the context of co-morbid disease. However, the study is limited in that it is purely computational and based on secondary (public) transcriptomic datasets; there is no experimental or clinical validation of the proposed signatures or drug targets. Moreover, because the datasets derive from different sources (with potential batch effects, differences in sample handling, heterogeneity of patient populations), the overlap of genes may partly reflect technical or sampling artifacts rather than true biological intersection. The approach also does not resolve causality (i.e., whether COVID-19 drives those changes in lung cancer, or vice versa). Finally, since the analysis focuses on lung cancer patients and shared genes, the findings may not generalize to noncancer populations or reflect complexities of the in vivo microenvironment (e.g., spatial heterogeneity, tumor‚Äìimmune cell interactions).

üêÅKim et al. present a xenograft model in immunodeficient mice using human Calu-3 lung cells to sustain in vivo long-term replication of SARS-CoV-2 over 30 days. Within the tumor xenografts, virus persisted, accumulated mutations (predominantly in the spike protein), and certain variants arose that showed greater replication in the Calu-3 environment without cytopathic effect. When tested in K18-ACE2 mice, the variant isolates were attenuated (less lethal) relative to the parental strain, yet induced cross-reactive neutralizing antibodies and protective immunity upon rechallenge. This model demonstrates how SARS-CoV-2 can evolve under prolonged replication pressure in a permissive tissue niche, yielding variants with altered replication‚Äìvirulence trade-offs. However, because the host mice are immunodeficient and lack immunological selective pressures, and because the experiment spans only 30 days, the extent to which the mutations and dynamics recapitulate persistent infection in humans is uncertain.

This review article collates and synthesizes existing evidence on the role of the chaperone protein HSPA5 (GRP78/BiP) when expressed on the cell surface, particularly its overexpression in many cancers and its potential role as a SARS-CoV-2 receptor or cofactor. The authors argue that because HSPA5 is highly expressed in many tumors and possibly upregulated under stress, it represents a plausible alternative or supplementary entry point for the virus, especially in malignancy contexts. They further describe docking and expression analyses suggesting that SARS-CoV-2 spike variants could bind HSPA5, and propose that targeting HSPA5 (via antibodies, small molecules, or natural products) might have therapeutic or prognostic value in both cancer and COVID-19.

Viruses account for roughly 10‚Äì15% of human cancers. This review explains that viral oncogenesis converges on DNA damage and genomic instability: viral oncoproteins inactivate tumor suppressors (e.g., p53/pRB) and chronic inflammation/oxidative stress from infection and co-factors (smoking, alcohol, radiation, co-infections) create DNA breaks that fuel mutations and chromosomal aberrations. For viruses like HPV, HBV and MCV, integration of viral DNA into host genomes is a pivotal carcinogenic trigger that elevates oncogene expression; activation yet manipulation of DNA damage response pathways (e.g., ATM/Chk2) further enables transformation. Given decade-long latencies, the authors highlight opportunities for prevention and early interception but note that antioxidant strategies remain unproven.

The paper shows that ambient PM2.5 is associated with higher rates of EGFR-mutant lung adenocarcinoma in never-smokers across multiple cohorts. In engineered mouse lungs that already carry EGFR/KRAS drivers, brief PM2.5 exposure promotes tumor formation via inflammation‚Äîespecially macrophage-derived IL-1Œ≤‚Äîthat shifts mutant AT2 cells into a regenerative, tumor-permissive state. Ultra-deep sequencing reveals that many ‚Äúhealthy‚Äù lungs already contain rare EGFR or KRAS driver mutations, implying that pollution mainly promotes cancers from existing clones rather than initiating them. This promotion model helps explain lung cancer in never-smokers and underscores the value of air-quality policies and potentially anti-inflammatory interception strategies targeting IL-1Œ≤.

üß´This work demonstrates that the SARS-CoV-2 membrane (M) protein augments malignant characteristics in triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) cells, enhancing migration, invasion, proliferation, stemness, and metastasis in vivo, mediated through activation of NFŒ∫B and STAT3 signaling and upregulation of inflammatory cytokines and EMT genes. In contrast, a more hormone-dependent breast cancer cell line (MCF-7) was less responsive to direct M protein treatment in terms of proliferation and metastasis. Moreover, M protein‚Äìtreated aggressive BCCs can exert paracrine influences on otherwise non-aggressive BCCs, driving them toward more malignant phenotypes via secreted cytokines and EMT induction. The findings raise the possibility that SARS-CoV-2 infection might exacerbate breast cancer progression, particularly in TNBC patients, and suggest that inhibition of NFŒ∫B or STAT3 pathways might ameliorate such adverse effects.
