However, translation to human disease remains speculative, pending further validation in clinical and primary tumor settings.

MALAT1 is a long non-coding RNA that, although non-coding, can influence gene regulation by binding to miRNAs, RNAs, proteins, or chromatin, thereby modulating processes such as apoptosis, proliferation, migration, EMT, and inflammation. This review highlights evidence that MALAT1 is dysregulated in multiple lung pathologies (e.g. asthma, COPD, ARDS, IPF, pulmonary hypertension, lung cancer), with multiple proposed mechanistic axes (miRNA sponging, signaling pathway regulation) linking MALAT1 to disease processes. Experimental targeting of MALAT1 (e.g. via antisense oligonucleotides or pharmacological agents) in preclinical models has shown potential in mitigating lung injury or remodeling. While the review is comprehensive in mapping the literature, the authors also stress that many of the existing findings are from in vitro or animal studies, and causal, in vivo confirmation (especially in human tissues) remains limited. They highlight gaps such as small sample sizes, imbalance or heterogeneity in datasets, lack of mechanistic/histological validation in some disease contexts, and the need for translational and clinical assessment before MALAT1-based diagnostics or therapies can be reliably considered.

Severe long-COVID patients (selected from >1,000 non-hospitalized infections) showed high, persistent anti-SARS-CoV-2 IgG and heightened innate signatures, but blunted expansion of memory CD8‚Å∫ T cells. Plasma viral markers were inconsistently positive across assays, suggesting that serology (elevated IgG) may be a more sensitive surrogate of ongoing antigen exposure than current blood persistence assays. These findings support viral persistence as a driver of severe long COVID and argue for exploring extended antiviral therapy to target potential tissue reservoirs. Symptom/immunologic patterns didn‚Äôt form clear clusters, underscoring long COVID‚Äôs heterogeneity.

This study followed 55 infected healthcare workers during the Delta wave to compare SARS-CoV-2 viral-load decline after no vaccination, a single ChAdOx1 dose, or two ChAdOx1 doses given <6 weeks apart. By day 5 after PCR positivity, the single-dose group showed significantly lower viral RNA and a faster early decline than both the short-interval double-dose group and the unvaccinated. The authors suggest that when the second ChAdOx1 dose is given too soon, anti-vector (adenoviral) immunity may dampen the desired effect, leading to a slower fall in viral RNA. Because the cohort was small, observational, and confined to Delta-era HCWs, and because outcomes were PCR RNA rather than cultured virus or transmission events, the findings mainly highlight a possible short-term kinetic disadvantage of short-interval ChAdOx1 boosting‚Äînot a definitive statement on infectiousness or on other vaccines/variants.

This study examined chest CT scans of COVID-19 patients in Vietnam, documenting that lung abnormalities are common even in mild and moderate disease (up to ~45 %) and identifying ground-glass opacities, consolidations, opacities, and nodular lesions as the dominant patterns. Patients infected with the Delta variant had more severe lung injury patterns compared to those with Alpha or Omicron, and individuals vaccinated with at least two doses had lower risk of CT-detectable lung injury. Interestingly, younger patients (<18 years) were less likely to exhibit lung abnormalities, but the extent of lung injury on imaging did not clearly alter treatment outcomes in this cohort. The authors suggest that CT imaging might help detect otherwise subclinical lung damage in COVID-19, even in cases classified clinically as mild, to better guide management and prevent complications. They also interpret that non-Omicron strains tend to impose more lung burden and that vaccination confers a protective effect on lung involvement. However, they note that imaging findings do not necessarily translate into worse outcomes and should be interpreted in clinical context.

Choi et al. conducted a serosurvey among 79 domestic cats in New York City during 2020‚Äì2021, detecting SARS-CoV-2‚Äìspecific antibodies in 16% overall (and up to 44% in fall 2020). Over half of those antibody-positive cats also had measurable neutralizing activity. There was no clear correlation between seropositivity and respiratory symptoms or typical demographic factors. The study supports the notion that spillover from humans to cats occurred during the early pandemic, even if cat infections were largely subclinical. The study is limited by its modest sample size and the fact that the cats were drawn from an animal hospital population rather than a randomized community sample, raising potential sampling bias. Temporal sampling was uneven, and the high prevalence in fall 2020 may reflect selection or outbreak effects rather than stable prevalence. The study is cross-sectional (with limited longitudinal follow-up), so it cannot resolve directionality of transmission (e.g. cat-to-human) or dynamics of viral shedding. Finally, the serological and neutralization assays, while sensitive, cannot distinguish between recent versus past infection, nor necessarily detect low-level exposures.

This study profiled post-mortem brainstem, cerebellum, and olfactory tissues from individuals who died of COVID-19 at different disease stages using single-nucleus transcriptomics, spatial transcriptomics, and proteomics. In acute cases, the brainstem showed a pronounced type I interferon inflammatory response that was attenuated in late-phase cases. Spatial mapping revealed two patterns: a neuronal response centered on cranial nerve nuclei and a diffuse perivascular pattern involving oligodendrocytes, microglia, and astrocytes. The authors infer that local immune reactions, likely triggered by systemic inflammation, can disturb brain function without ongoing viral persistence in the CNS. This provides a plausible explanation for neurologic symptoms during and after acute infection and emphasizes neuroinflammation‚Äînot direct neurotropism‚Äîas a key mechanism.

This study used data from the UK Biobank to compare 112,311 individuals with a history of SARS-CoV-2 infection to large control cohorts and found consistently higher risks of developing chronic respiratory diseases such as asthma (HR 1.49), bronchiectasis (1.30), COPD (1.59), interstitial lung disease (1.81), pulmonary vascular disease (1.59), and lung cancer (1.39) over a median follow-up of ~0.8 years (up to 2.7 years). The risks were higher among those with more severe COVID-19, and analyses over time showed that the risk of asthma and bronchiectasis continued rising while risks for COPD, ILD, PVD and lung cancer declined. In those with SARS-CoV-2 reinfection versus a single infection, the hazards for respiratory outcomes were even more elevated (e.g. asthma HR ~3.0).

In a cohort of 207 Indian adults (mean age 48.7 years, 68.1% male), assessed on average 63 days after COVID-19 onset, 35% exhibited a restrictive ventilatory defect (TLC < 80%), 8.3% had obstructive defect, and 44.4% had reduced diffusing capacity (DLCO < 80%). Those who suffered COVID-19 pneumonia (moderate to critical WHO categories) had significantly worse lung function (e.g. FVC% 77.85 vs 88.18, DLCO% 75.30 vs 89.20), lower exercise oxygen saturations (94.89% vs 97.73%), and worse quality-of-life by SGRQ (mean 29.2 vs 11.0) than the mild group. Additionally, severe/critical cases had more pronounced radiographic abnormalities (RALE score median 1.5 vs 0) and functional deficits.

üêÅIn K18-hACE2 mice, intranasal SARS-CoV-2 caused marked blood-brain barrier (BBB) disruption by 5 days, with IgG leakage, microhemorrhages, loss of ZO-1/Claudin-5, and pericyte depletion. The vasculature showed endothelial activation (VCAM1, COX-2) and brain tissue exhibited astrogliosis (GFAP) and microglial activation (IBA1). Similar barrier breakdown and inflammatory signatures were found at the choroid plexus blood ‚Äì cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) barrier. Many outcomes were significant with n = 3; p < 0.001. Brain sections stained positive for SARS-CoV-2 nucleocapsid protein.

This study of 18 patients with peripheral arterial thrombosis (7 of whom had prior SARS-CoV-2 positivity) found SARS-CoV-2 RNA in 50% of endothelial biopsies and all thrombotic clots, with viral nucleoprotein detected in 15% of endothelium and 50% of clots. Patients with viral presence had significantly lower plasma levels of the anticoagulant PROS1, and among them, those whose tissue was positive for virus had even lower PROS1 than those without. Viral entry receptor ACE2 and CD147 were upregulated in affected tissues from SARS-CoV-2‚Äìpositive patients. The authors propose that in situ vascular persistence of SARS-CoV-2 may enable localized cleavage of PROS1 by the viral papain-like protease (PLpro), impairing anticoagulant balance and contributing to COVID-19‚Äìassociated coagulopathies.

This population-level longitudinal study followed 6,833,423 residents of Madrid over the first three years of the COVID-19 pandemic (2020‚Äì2022), linking administrative and clinical registries to quantify confirmed infections, hospitalizations, and 30-day mortality. About 21.4% of residents had a confirmed COVID-19 diagnosis and 1.5% required hospitalization. The 30-day mortality among confirmed infections was 1.6%, declining over time (from 11.4% early 2020 to 0.4% in early 2022), while among hospitalized patients the 30-day mortality was 10.8%, decreasing from 14.0% to 6.0% over the same period. Risk of death was higher with older age, male gender, greater socioeconomic deprivation, and underlying comorbidities, reflecting consistent predictors of worse outcomes. The authors present this as a framework for cross-regional comparisons of COVID-19 burden. However, limitations include possible underascertainment of infections, reliance on administrative coding, lack of variant-level or long-term outcome analyses, and limited generalizability to other settings.

This study used a bidirectional Mendelian randomization framework to test whether genetically determined leukocyte telomere length causally influences COVID-19 susceptibility or severity. Using ~20 LTL‚Äêassociated SNPs and large genome-wide association studies (GWAS) datasets from the COVID-19 Host Genetics Initiative (e.g. 38,984 cases vs 1,644,784 controls for susceptibility), the authors found no significant associations in either direction, and no detectable genetic correlation between telomere length and COVID-19 outcomes. Sensitivity analyses and alternate instrument sets yielded consistent null results. While observational studies had linked shorter telomeres to more severe COVID-19, the MR evidence here argues against a strong causal role of telomere length (as proxied by common genetic variants) in COVID-19 risk or severity‚Äîat least in European ancestry populations. The authors caution that their power is limited (instruments explain only a small proportion of LTL variance), and nonlinear effects or contributions of extremely short telomeres cannot be excluded.

In a case‚Äìcontrol study of 117 COVID-19 survivors versus 144 controls, the authors report significant biological age acceleration in survivors (DeltaAge 10.45 ¬± 7.29 years vs 3.68 ¬± 8.17; p < 0.0001). 76.6% of survivors were classified as biologically ‚Äúolder‚Äù than expected. The effect was strongest in participants <60 years, with no sex differences. Survivors also had shorter leukocyte telomeres (3.03 ¬± 2.39 kb vs 10.67 ¬± 11.69 kb, p < 0.0001) and lower ACE2 mRNA in blood (0.000380 vs 0.001390 2^‚àíŒîCt; p < 0.0001); DPP-4 expression was unchanged. The authors suggest SARS-CoV-2 may leave a persistent aging-like epigenetic and telomeric footprint consistent with post-COVID sequelae. However, the study is cross-sectional without pre-infection baselines, uses a limited 4-CpG clock, and shows group imbalances (e.g., BMI, lung disease). Results should be validated with longitudinal, multi-clock epigenetic profiling and standardized TL assays across diverse tissues and cohorts.

This review argues that persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection‚Äîongoing replication lasting well beyond the acute phase‚Äîoccurs in a subset of patients, particularly the immunocompromised, and is likely under-recognized. The authors highlight tissue reservoirs (including outside the lungs) as a key driver, emphasize the need for diagnostics that detect replication rather than mere exposure, and warn that within-host evolution during these prolonged courses can generate variants with immune-escape potential. They call for standardized definitions, tailored treatment strategies (e.g., extended/combination antivirals and case-specific antibody approaches), and surveillance to track intra-host evolution and potential spread.

This cross-sectional study of U.S. adults using the 2022 BRFSS survey estimated that about 21.7 % of people with prior COVID-19 reported persistent post-COVID symptoms. The most common complaints were fatigue (5.7 %), shortness of breath (4.2 %), and loss of smell or taste (3.8 %). After adjusting for covariates, risk factors for long COVID included female sex, overweight or obesity (BMI ‚â• 25), being uninsured, prior pulmonary disease, depression, arthritis, former smoking status, and shorter sleep duration (< 7 hours). Older age (> 64 years), Black race, and higher household income were paradoxically associated with lower odds of reporting long COVID.

This study links brain fog in long COVID to blood‚Äìbrain barrier (BBB) leakiness measured with DCE-MRI in 11 brain-fog patients versus 11 long-COVID without brain fog and 10 recovered controls; leakage localized to bilateral temporal and frontal regions. Blood profiling in 76 acute COVID patients showed graded increases in inflammatory and endothelial/coagulation markers with severity, and higher S100Œ≤ in those with brain fog. Structural MRI (vs 60 healthy controls) found reduced brain/white-matter volumes and increased CSF in brain-fog patients, with BBB disruption correlating with these changes. Mechanistically, PBMC RNA-seq suggested coagulation dysregulation and dampened adaptive immunity in brain-fog; long-COVID PBMCs adhered more to brain endothelium, and patient serum or S1 spike protein activated endothelial cells (‚ÜëTNF/TGFŒ≤/ICAM1/VCAM1). The authors propose that sustained systemic inflammation plus focal BBB dysfunction underlies cognitive symptoms and highlight TGF-Œ≤ as a candidate biomarker/target.

This article argues that the enigma of long COVID offers a unique opportunity to understand how a viral infection can transition into a chronic, multi-system disease. The authors survey plausible biological mechanisms‚Äîviral persistence, immune dysregulation, endothelial/microvascular injury, latent virus reactivation, autonomic dysfunction, and metabolic disruption‚Äîwhile emphasizing that long COVID is likely heterogeneous rather than a single uniform disease. They call for deeper mechanistic, tissue-based, and longitudinal studies to discriminate causal drivers from secondary signals. They also highlight that some early empirical findings support components of this framework (e.g. persistent viral antigens in plasma, viral RNA in tissues), but emphasize the urgent need for stronger causal evidence, standardized cohorts, biomarker platforms, and interventional trials. The authors conclude that solving long COVID could illuminate general principles of post-infectious sequelae and pave the path toward precision therapeutics.

This WHO-affiliated systematic review/meta-analysis pooled 182 studies (10,023 participants) to quantify SARS-CoV-2 RNA in body fluids relevant to sexual activity. Pooled detection was 82.6% in saliva, 31.8% in faeces/rectal swabs, 3.8% in urine, 2.7% in vaginal secretions, and 1.6% in semen; viable virus was reported in saliva and faeces. Reported maximum persistence reached 210 days in faeces/rectal secretions, 121 days in semen, 112 days in saliva, 77 days in urine, and 13 days in vaginal fluids. The findings suggest that while sexual transmission via semen/vaginal fluids appears unlikely (low detection and no culture positivity), intimate contact remains a risk through saliva and potential faecal exposure.

Using a nationwide Scottish cohort of 198,096 adults (98,666 infected; 99,430 matched never-infected), the authors estimated the true prevalence of long-COVID by subtracting background symptom rates seen in never-infected people and adjusting for confounders. They found an adjusted attributable prevalence of 6.6% at 6 months, 6.5% at 12 months, and 10.4% at 18 months after infection; crude gaps were 13.8%, 12.8%, and 16.3%, respectively. Attributable prevalence was higher in women and in later variant periods (Alpha ~3.9% vs Delta ~6.7% and Omicron ~7.9% at 6 months). Because symptoms are largely non-specific and assessment relied on self-report with PCR-based ascertainment (no antigen tests), misclassification and residual confounding remain important limitations.

In a RECOVER-EHR study across 40 U.S. pediatric hospitals during the Omicron (Jan 2022‚ÄìOct 2023) period, the 6-month incidence of Long COVID was ~904 per million after a first infection vs ~1,884 per million after a second‚Äîmore than doubling risk. Elevated risks spanned demographics, vaccination status, and initial illness severity. Sequelae with higher post-reinfection risk included myocarditis, blood clots, acute kidney injury, respiratory symptoms, fatigue, and cognitive issues.

This prospective observational study in Turkey compared 30 infants who had SARS-CoV-2 infection in the neonatal period (‚â• 34 weeks gestation) with 60 matched controls to assess neurodevelopment at 18‚Äì24 months using the Bayley-II scale. The SARS-CoV-2‚Äìpositive group showed worse psychomotor development (PDI) and more mildly delayed performances (MDPs; PDI p = 0.05, MDPs p = 0.03). Among those infected with the Delta variant, both mental (MDI) and psychomotor (PDI) scores were significantly lower (p = 0.03 for both). The infected infants also had reduced head circumference during the first year (p < 0.001), though by the second year, the head circumference difference had largely resolved.

This paper reports on four individuals with B-cell depletion (from rituximab, one also on epcoritamab) who developed persistent SARS-CoV-2 infection over periods from 45 to 242 days, which was difficult to diagnose because upper airway PCR tests occasionally became negative; in two cases, only bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) sampling revealed persistent viral presence. After the persistent infection was identified, all four patients were treated with antiviral therapies (including remdesivir, nirmatrelvir/ritonavir, or a combination), and viral clearance was eventually achieved in all.

In a cohort of 7,039 undergraduates at a Spanish university during the 2020‚Äì21 year, 658 (9.3 %) were diagnosed with COVID-19 via frequent PCR testing. Among the infected, only 4.0 % achieved ‚Äúoutstanding academic‚Äù performance versus 7.3 % in the uninfected group. Adjusted regression analysis yielded an odds ratio of 0.57 (95 % CI 0.38‚Äì0.86), indicating that SARS-CoV-2 infection was significantly associated with lower likelihood of top academic marks.

In a case‚Äìcontrol study six months after COVID-19 (n=37 convalescents; controls n=40), the authors found reduced PD-1 on CD8+ T cells in convalescents and elevated plasma IFN-Œ≥ (with lower IL-7). Convalescent plasma lowered PD-1 on T cells from healthy donors, and IFN-Œ≥ neutralization restored PD-1 on CD8+ cells. Spike protein‚Äîbut not nucleocapsid‚Äîprovoked IFN-Œ≥ responses only in convalescents (ELISpot n=6). Single-cell analyses and perturbation experiments suggest IFN-Œ≥ reduces PD-1 via the AKT/GSK3Œ≤ pathway (AKT agonism and inhibition modulated PD-1 and p-GSK3Œ≤ accordingly). About 35% reported lingering symptoms. Overall, the work proposes an IFN-Œ≥‚ÜîPD-1 axis that could sustain pre-exhausted CD8+ T cells months after infection, a potential immunologic substrate for long-COVID features.

This study uses a Bayesian hierarchical model to generate monthly estimates of excess mortality in 3,127 U.S. counties from March 2020 to February 2022, finding 1,179,024 excess deaths during that period (634,830 in the first year, 544,194 in the second). The relative excess mortality (excess vs expected deaths) fell in large metropolitan counties from ~24.0 % in year 1 to ~17.1 % in year 2, while it rose in non-metropolitan areas from ~20.2 % to ~21.9 %. The spatial pattern of excess deaths shifted over time: early in the pandemic, excess mortality clustered in large urban counties (especially in the Northeast), but later waves brought stronger increases in rural counties, particularly in the South and West. The authors attribute part of this shift to differential vaccination uptake, rural health resource constraints, and challenges in accurate death attribution, and call for more attention to rural communities and improvements in mortality surveillance.

Researchers profiled PBMC immune subsets in 24 children and 41 adults with first-wave, primary SARS-CoV-2 infection (sampling at ~11‚Äì12 days post-symptom onset), analyzed 57 adult samples across mild/moderate/severe disease, and followed 18 adults through recovery. Adults displayed more lung-homing CCR4+ CD8+ T cells and exhausted CD56^dim NK cells, while children had fewer lung-homing CD8 cells and an IFN-prone CD56^bright NK exhaustion profile; children also showed more CD5+ translational B cells. Severity-linked patterns included higher IgM memory B cells and atypical CD11c+ IgD+CD27+ B2 cells in mild cases, versus more Igs‚àí B cells, CD56^dim CX3CR1+ NK, CCR6^hi CD28^hi CD4 T_cm, and PD-1+ TIGIT+ CD8 T_em in severe cases. Several severity-associated subsets (e.g., IgM memory B cells) remained stable during recovery (~2 months), suggesting baseline immune features tied to susceptibility; others (e.g., CX3CR1+ NK) declined (p = 3.0√ó10‚Åª¬≥), consistent with infection-related signatures.

This study, leveraging large national cohorts in South Korea and Japan, found that individuals who had COVID-19 between 2020‚Äì2021 had a modestly elevated risk of developing autoimmune inflammatory rheumatic diseases (AIRD) over the subsequent months compared to matched uninfected controls (adjusted hazard ratio ~1.25 in Korea) and compared to individuals with influenza (aHR ~1.30). The risk was higher in those with more severe acute COVID-19, and similar patterns were observed across both countries. Vaccination against COVID-19 appeared to attenuate the increased risk, except in the subgroup with severe infection.

In a study of 30 Long COVID patients (symptoms > 3 months), 10 recovered COVID individuals, and 20 healthy controls, the authors report that megakaryocytes (MKs) in Long COVID patients are more frequent in peripheral blood (0.28 ¬± 0.05% vs. 0.03 ¬± 0.02% in healthy) and carry both SARS-CoV-2 single- and double-stranded RNA and Spike protein. These virus-harboring MKs appear to produce platelets that also contain viral RNA and Spike, and microclots were observed in all Long COVID participants. Additionally, about 30% of Long COVID patients had detectable Spike protein in plasma (at picogram levels), and levels of platelet serotonin and the enzyme TPH-1 were significantly reduced in LC versus recovered individuals.

In a large Norwegian cohort (~112k people with known test status; ~153k questionnaires), self-reported memory function (Everyday Memory Questionnaire (EMQ), 0‚Äì4 scale) was consistently worse after a positive SARS-CoV-2 test than after a negative test, across 0‚Äì36 months. Adjusted mean EMQ scores for positives vs negatives were 0.66 vs 0.60 at 0‚Äì1 month and 0.82 vs 0.62 at 12‚Äì18 and 18‚Äì36 months; the two groups were similar before testing (0.61 vs 0.60). Worse scores tracked with more days bedridden (e.g., 1.29 if >13 days). The authors emphasize these are mild deficits on average and self-reported. Limitations include potential recall and response bias, residual confounding, and lack of objective cognitive testing. Still, the pattern suggests a persistent association between COVID-19 and perceived memory problems up to three years post-infection.

In a pediatric case-control study (56 long-COVID patients vs 27 controls; mean ages ~10 y), 24-hour Holter analyses found significant heart-rate-variability (HRV) shifts in the long-COVID group: lower r-MSSD and higher VLF, LF, and HF power. Conventional echocardiography was normal in both groups. These findings suggest a cardiac autonomic imbalance‚Äîwith relative parasympathetic predominance‚Äîas a physiologic correlate of long-COVID symptoms in youth.

In a virology sub-study nested within the PANORAMIC trial, nonhospitalized, at-risk adults with early symptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection were randomized to receive a 5-day course of molnupiravir (n = 253) or usual care (n = 324). Although molnupiravir accelerated viral decline during treatment (viral half-life ~0.41 days vs ~0.72 days in usual care), by Day 14 the molnupiravir group showed significantly higher viral RNA persistence and lower anti-spike antibody titers (~2,200 U/mL lower). Modeling suggested that to suppress viral RNA below detection in 95 % of patients might require a longer (‚âà10-day) regimen. Genomic sequencing revealed that molnupiravir-treated viruses carried increased mutational burdens (on average ~180 extra mutations, higher transition:transversion ratios) and greater diversity. Among residual virus, ~16.7 % of tested samples were culture-positive, with some viable virus detectable up to 9 days post-treatment. No strong signal of consensus-level spike escape mutations was found yet several recurrent substitutions in polymerase and nonstructural proteins emerged. The authors caution that the standard 5-day molnupiravir course may be too short, potentially risking persistence of mutated virus and attenuated antibody responses, and they suggest that longer treatment durations warrant investigation.

This preprint reports that 25 adults who had mild to moderate COVID-19 showed on average a 2.65-year increase in MRI-predicted brain age (Brain Age Gap) compared to 24 noninfected controls, and 80% of the COVID group displayed accelerated brain aging versus 13% in controls. The elevated BAG correlated with poorer performance on cognitive tests assessing attention, processing speed, and executive function. Female sex strongly reduced the odds of accelerated aging (OR = 0.015), and a longer interval since infection was modestly associated with reduced risk of accelerated BAG.

This mini-review (April 28, 2023) compiles evidence that Long COVID disproportionately affects premenopausal women and can disrupt female reproductive health‚Äîmenstrual cycles, ovarian function, fertility, and symptom patterns around menses‚Äîwhile also interacting with pregnancy and menopause. Data points include 33.8% reporting menstrual problems in a 1,792-person LC survey (irregular cycles 26%; heavy bleeding 19.7%) and higher odds of cycle changes vs. general populations (OR 1.34). Case reports describe premature ovarian insufficiency months after infection; in a small prospective cohort of COVID-positive pregnant patients (n=84), 75.9% developed LC-consistent persistence, and glucocorticoid exposure was linked to greater risk of persistent fatigue (RR 6.92). Given the paucity of direct LC studies, the authors review overlapping conditions common in LC‚ÄîME/CFS, POTS, EDS, endometriosis‚Äîconditions that are 70‚Äì80% female and carry elevated risks of dysmenorrhea, amenorrhea/oligomenorrhea, dyspareunia, infertility, fibroids/bleeding, and adverse pregnancy outcomes.

Tang et al. performed a comparative cross-sectional study of plasma soluble factors and neuronal-enriched extracellular vesicle (nEV) cargo in 33 individuals with persistent neurological symptoms after COVID-19 (nLongC), 12 recovered individuals without lingering symptoms (Cov), and 28 pre-COVID healthy controls. They found that IL-1Œ≤ was elevated in both COVID-19 groups, while IL-8 was elevated only in the nLongC group; BDNF and cortisol were also increased in both groups compared to controls. In nEVs, the nLongC group showed marked upregulation of proteins linked to neurodegeneration (AŒ≤42, pTau181, TDP-43, etc.), whereas the Cov group showed more limited changes (only AŒ≤40). These findings support the hypothesis that SARS-CoV-2 infection can lead to chronic peripheral inflammation and sustained stress responses, and may drive pathological changes in neuronal vesicle cargo associated with neurodegeneration.

In a large adaptive, community-based randomized trial (PRINCIPLE), Hayward et al. tested ivermectin (300‚Äì400 Œºg/kg daily for 3 days) versus usual care in 8,811 SARS-CoV-2 positive adult outpatients. The ivermectin arm had a modest acceleration in time to self-reported recovery (HR 1.15, median ~2.06 days faster), but the probability that this effect reached a pre-specified clinically meaningful threshold (HR ‚â• 1.2) was low (‚âà 19 %). Hospitalization or death outcomes did not differ (OR 1.02, CrI 0.63‚Äì1.62), and long-term recovery (e.g. at 6 months) was similar between groups (74.3 % vs 71.2 %).

This case‚Äêcontrol study evaluated 22 SARS survivors unable to resume work 13 to 36 months post-infection and compared them with healthy controls and fibromyalgia patients. The post-SARS group exhibited persistent fatigue, diffuse muscle pain, depression, and unrefreshing sleep. In polysomnography, they showed signs of sleep instability‚Äîelevated cyclical alternating pattern rates, REM-related apneas/hypopneas, and an alpha EEG anomaly‚Äîparalleling features seen in fibromyalgia and chronic fatigue syndrome.

In a cohort study leveraging US Veterans Affairs healthcare data, Xu et al. (2022) assessed the 12-month risk of new neurologic disorders in 154,068 individuals who survived the acute phase of COVID-19, comparing them to over 5.6 million contemporary controls and 5.9 million historical controls. They found a hazard ratio of ~1.42 (95% CI 1.38‚Äì1.47) for any incident neurologic outcome, corresponding to an excess burden of ~70.7 cases per 1,000 persons over 12 months. Elevated risks were seen across diverse domains ‚Äî cerebrovascular disease, memory and cognition, peripheral nerve disorders, movement disorders, mental health, sensory and musculoskeletal manifestations, Guillain‚ÄìBarr√© syndrome, and encephalitis/encephalopathy. These risks held even for nonhospitalized COVID-19 cases and increased in severity with more intensive acute care settings.

In this large retrospective cohort study of 106,428 individuals with deliveries across seven U.S. states, COVID-19 vaccination during pregnancy (‚â•2 mRNA doses) was associated with lower maternal SARS-CoV-2 infection rates (4.0% vs. 5.3%, p < 0.0001) and improved birth outcomes (preterm birth 7.9% vs. 9.4%, stillbirth 0.3% vs. 0.6%, very low birthweight 1.0% vs. 1.5%) compared to matched unvaccinated individuals. Boosted pregnant individuals (‚â•3 doses) showed further reduction in infection (3.2% vs. 5.6%, p < 0.0001) and a lower stillbirth risk (0.3% vs. 0.5%, p < 0.025) relative to vaccinated but unboosted peers, though differences in preterm birth and very low birthweight did not reach statistical significance.

Across 18 U.S. jurisdictions (‚âà45% of population), the share of COVID-19 cases that were reinfections jumped from 2.7% during Delta to 10.3% (BA.1), 12.5% (BA.2), 20.6% (BA.4/BA.5), and 28.8% during BQ.1/BQ.1.1; overall 12.7% of 21.9 million cases were reinfections. The share of hospitalizations occurring during reinfections rose from 1.9% (Delta) to 17.0% (BQ.1/BQ.1.1); for deaths, from 1.2% to 12.3% across the same periods. The median time between infections peaked at 411 days (mid-Feb 2022) and later shortened to 335 days in mid-June 2022 before ending the year at 367 days. Findings indicate increasing reinfection frequency and growing shares of severe outcomes occurring during reinfection as Omicron sublineages spread. Limitations include partial jurisdiction coverage, under-ascertainment from unreported tests, use of a >90-day reinfection definition, and ecological assignment of variant periods rather than sequence-confirmed lineages.

In 147 vaccinated workers with prior mild or asymptomatic COVID-19, blood biomarkers of CNS injury‚ÄîsNfL and sGFAP‚Äîwere significantly elevated ~1 week after recovery versus 82 healthy controls, with p < 0.001 for both. Those with early cognitive failure (CFQ ‚â•43; 7.5%) had markedly higher sNfL and sGFAP (both p = 0.005). At ~10 months, biomarkers declined (median sNfL 18.3, sGFAP 77.2 pg/mL) but remained above controls; meanwhile, mean CFQ scores increased (18.1 ‚Üí 27.1; p < 0.01), and 14.3% met the CFQ threshold, though without biomarker differences by CFQ at that time. The authors infer persistent neuronal/astroglial injury after mild infection but note important limitations: single-center, loss to follow-up, self-reported cognition, and no imaging/CSF or pre-infection baseline.

This large community study (n = 112,964 completers) used an online 8-task battery and found small, measurable cognitive deficits following COVID-19. Deficits were most pronounced in memory, reasoning, and executive function. Individuals with ongoing symptoms ‚â•12 weeks showed the largest global deficit (‚àí0.42 SD), whereas those who had recovered‚Äîwhether their illness lasted <4 weeks or had previously persisted ‚â•12 weeks‚Äîshowed smaller deficits (about ‚àí0.23 to ‚àí0.24 SD) compared with never-infected controls. Deficits were larger for infections during early variants (original/Alpha) than Omicron (e.g., Alpha vs Omicron ‚âà ‚àí0.17 SD) and worse with hospitalization/ICU (ICU ‚âà ‚àí0.35 SD). The authors caution that these are small effect sizes, gathered in an online, self-selected sample, so causality and clinical impact remain uncertain; nevertheless, effects were still detectable ‚â•1 year post-infection.

Al-Aly & Rosen‚Äôs NEJM editorial reviews evidence that long COVID commonly involves objective cognitive deficits, not just subjective complaints. They spotlight a 112,964-person NEJM study showing deficits that persist ‚â•1 year, scale with illness severity and symptom persistence ‚â•12 weeks, and appear to abate when symptoms resolve; press coverage framed these effects as roughly 3‚Äì9 IQ-point equivalents depending on severity. Reinfection contributed an additional loss in IQ of nearly 2 points, as compared with no reinfection.

In a longitudinal analysis of 100 top-league attackers, 76% exhibited significant post-COVID changes in at least one of 28 technical match indicators. Fourteen indicators declined after infection‚Äîmost notably five scoring-linked metrics (xG, npxG, xAG, SCA, GCA)‚Äîand several measures of possession, receiving, and take-ons also decreased. Recovery was relatively swift: players needed a mean of 3.09 matches to return to baseline (elite 2.64 vs control 3.55), and age showed little effect on either decline or recovery. The authors attribute short-term reductions to lingering physical readiness and training disruption rather than durable impairment.

In a cohort of 41 patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS), Kuchler et al. used retinal vessel analysis to examine microvascular endothelial function. They observed significantly reduced venular flicker-induced dilation (3.42% vs. 4.64%, p = 0.02), narrower arteriolar calibers (CRAE ~178.1 vs. 189.1, p = 0.01), and lower arteriolar-to-venular ratios (AVR ~0.84 vs. 0.88, p = 0.007) compared with matched healthy controls. A combined metric of AVR + vFID discriminated PCS patients from controls with area under curve = 0.75. Moreover, worse symptom severity correlated with lower AVR (R = ‚Äì0.37, p = 0.017), and these microvascular abnormalities were more pronounced in PCS patients with elevated inflammatory biomarker levels (e.g. CXCL10, IL-6). The authors argue that persistent endothelial dysfunction in the microcirculation is a potential pathophysiologic hallmark of long COVID, potentially explaining enduring symptoms such as fatigue and cognitive impairment. They propose that retinal vessel parameters may serve as noninvasive biomarkers in PCS and inform therapeutic strategies aiming to restore vascular health.

This review argues that long COVID involves persistent thromboinflammation, combining endothelial injury, hypercoagulability, platelet activation, and neutrophil NET formation. Together these changes favor micro- and macrovascular thrombosis, reflected by findings such as microclots, elevated D-dimer, and perfusion defects in lungs and brain; survivors of COVID-19 also have increased rates of arterial/venous thromboses after the acute illness.

The authors propose a Bayesian-weighted mutation walker to simulate realistic evolutionary trajectories of the SARS-CoV Spike protein (using observed mutation frequencies), and then cluster and screen candidate lineages for both retained human-cell infectivity (via binding to hACE2) and altered antigenicity (reduced binding to a known neutralizing antibody). They show that one of the candidate ‚Äúchimeric‚Äù Spike variants (Spike1 / RBD1) recapitulates binding energetics close to SARS-CoV-2‚Äôs RBD‚ÄìhACE2 (‚Äì23.73 vs ‚Äì24.7; ‚Äì80.7 vs ‚Äì81.2 kcal/mol) yet has much weaker binding to the P2C-1F11 neutralizing antibody (‚Äì22.7 vs ‚Äì83.7 kcal/mol), suggesting that their method could have ‚Äúforeseen‚Äù a SARS-CoV-2‚Äìlike lineage from SARS-CoV-1. The authors argue that such in silico forecasting, combined with genomic surveillance and pre-emptive broad neutralization strategies, might reduce the severity of future SARS-CoV pandemics. However, the method is demonstrated only retrospectively, and there remain substantial uncertainties about how well computationally predicted lineages correspond to viable viruses in nature. The assay relies heavily on modeling assumptions, limited mutation frequency data, clustering heuristics, and idealized binding-energy estimates, without experimental validation or consideration of other evolutionary pressures (e.g. viral replication fitness, immune environment, host ecology). Thus, while conceptually interesting, the predictive power in real-world viral emergence remains speculative.

In this matched retrospective cohort study of hospitalized adults (6,614 in each group) from January 2022 to January 2023, the incidence of new post-acute sequelae between 90 and 180 days was higher among COVID-19 survivors (17.9 %) than influenza survivors (13.0 %), corresponding to a hazard ratio of 1.398 (95 % CI 1.251‚Äì1.562). The COVID-19 group also had higher risks of specific symptoms such as abnormal breathing, abdominal complaints, fatigue, and cognitive issues, and increased rates of all-cause emergency department visits, rehospitalizations, and death (27.5 % vs. 21.7 %, HR 1.303). Mortality alone was substantially higher (1.5 % vs. 0.4 %) in the COVID-19 group (HR 4.378).

In a survey of 11,697 adults in Western Australia who had a documented SARS-CoV-2 infection during the 2022 Omicron wave, 18.2 % met criteria for long COVID at 90 days post-infection. Women, middle-aged individuals (50‚Äì69 years), those with underlying health conditions, and participants who had received fewer vaccine doses had higher adjusted risks. The most common symptoms were fatigue (70.6 %) and cognitive difficulties (59.5 %). Over one-third (38.2 %) of those with long COVID consulted a GP in the preceding month, and 1.6 % had hospitalizations related to post-COVID symptoms. Among those previously employed or studying, 17.8 % reported reducing or discontinuing their activity due to residual symptoms.

This review posits that SARS-CoV-2 infection forces a sweeping rewiring of host cellular metabolism‚Äîsugar, lipid, amino acid, nucleotide, and redox pathways‚Äîby hijacking viral‚Äìhost protein interactions and essential host factors like ACE2, NRP1, furin, TMPRSS2, and CTSL. The authors argue that beyond the acute infection, a residual human metabolic reprogramming / dysregulation (HMRD) can persist even when the virus is cleared, providing a unifying mechanistic basis for many of the multi-system symptoms observed in long COVID (PASC). They categorize PASC sufferers into four sub-phenotypes based on dominant organ impairments and link them to underlying metabolic derangements.
